title: sunny day hiroshima 75 years atomic bomb
story: It is Monday 16 July 1945, 5.30 am, and a sodden night in the New Mexico desert is suddenly a sunny day.“The whole country was lighted by a searing light with the intensity many times that of the midday sun,” writes General Thomas Farrell, deputy commander of the Manhattan Project, the secret team in Los Alamos dedicated to creating the bomb. “It was golden, purple, violet, gray, and blue. It lighted every peak, crevasse, and ridge of the nearby mountain range with a clarity and beauty that cannot be described but must be seen to be imagined.”Just four hours after the ‘Trinity’ test, the first nuclear detonation in history, a ship leaves San Francisco, bound for Tinian Island in the South West Pacific. On board is Little Boy, only the second nuclear bomb ever created.That night the people of Hiroshima feel relatively safe. They have grown so used to American B-29 bombers passing overhead, they have nicknamed them ‘B-San’ or ‘Mr B’. Like the rest of the world, they have never heard of the atom bomb. They do not know that Hiroshima has deliberately been spared conventional bombing so its devastating effects will be clear. Little Boy’s final destination is still not set. The US Targeting Committee has narrowed the possible targets down to three: Hiroshima, Kokura and Nagasaki. The ultimate decision will be chosen based on prevailing weather conditions.6th August. 00.02 For the first time, the crew of the B-29 named Enola Gay is told what weapon they will be carrying. Captain William ‘Deak’ Parsons informs them it will be the most furious explosion since creation, that it might crack the Earth’s crust. In Hiroshima, it is a clear night full of shooting stars.02.45 The Enola Gay takes off. It has been named after pilot Colonel Paul Tibbett’s “courageous red-haired mother”. In Tibbett’s pocket are cyanide capsules, one for each member of his crew, in case of capture. As the aeroplane heaves itself into the air, the crew still do not know where they are heading.04.00 Dr Michihiko Hachiya, a physician at the Hiroshima Communications Hospital, finishes his air raid duty. There is nothing to report.06.41 Captain Parsons begins arming the warhead. He has taken it upon himself to do this en route, dismantling and reassembling Little Boy in the freezing bomb bay. Four heavily-laden B-29s have recently crashed taking off from the Tinian runway, which ends in a cliff. Little Boy weighs 9,700 lbs and required special sunken bays to be dug just to load it into the aircraft. The chance of catastrophe is too great.07.29 “The hour was early the morning still, warm, and beautiful,” Dr Hachiya noted in his diary. “Shimmering leaves, reflecting sunlight from a cloudless sky, made a pleasant contrast with shadows in my garden as I gazed absently through wide-flung doors opening to the south.”High above, the weather plane assigned to check conditions in Hiroshima ahead of the mission passes over the city. An air raid siren greets it, but it’s just Mr B making his rounds. Only now is the target set.08.14 Bombardier Thomas Ferebee on board Enola Gay spots the Aioi Hashi, a T-shaped bridge at the heart of the city. A tone warns the crew of the aircraft to brace themselves. The citizens of Hiroshima hear nothing but a distant thrum. There is no siren. The fireball is hotter than the surface of the sun. Almost everything within one mile of the centre is vaporised instantly. Winds of more than 650 miles per hour turn every shard of wood not immediately incinerated into shrapnel. One quarter of a city of 350,000 are killed instantly. The mountains that surround the city, which gave Hiroshima such pleasant weather, produce a ‘focussing effect’ for the shockwave.The bomb is a grotesque act of creation. It took some of the world’s finest and most creative minds, and $2 billion (more than £18 billion in today’s money), to bring it to life. At the moment of detonation it replaces the historic city of Hiroshima with something new. Hiroshima was known as Mizu no Miyako or the ‘City of Water’. Now it is, according to Dr Hachiya, “no longer a city but a burnt-over prairie”, a City of Fire.Naked survivors, the patterns of their clothes burned into their backs, wander dazed through the inferno, driven by an unbearable thirst. Many die in reservoirs, swimming pools and water tanks, or drown in the swift Ōta river. The outline of the sun through the dust is red. A black rain falls from the sky. Hiroshima is now, in a word repeated over and over again by survivors, “Hell.”It took J Robert Oppenheimer, father of the atomic bomb, 15 minutes to accept the possibility of fission, then a week to sketch Little Boy on his blackboard. He explained: “When you see something that is technically sweet, you go ahead and do it.”Yet at heart, Little Boy was barely more sophisticated than a medieval cannon, firing a uranium bullet down a tube into a target. The scientists were so confident the contraption would work, they never bothered to test it. The Trinity ‘gadget’ and Fat Man, the bomb later dropped on Nagasaki, were more sophisticated ‘implosion’ devices.The technology developed quickly after Hiroshima and Nagasaki. Massive weapons like the thermonuclear Tzar Bomba (thousands of times more powerful than Little Boy) gave way to missile defence shields like Ronald Reagan’s Star Wars, which in turn inspired smarter missiles. The creative spiral was only averted by bans and treaties that are now decaying. There are currently around 14,000 nuclear weapons in the world, down from a high of 70,000 in 1986. How does Little Boy compare to their power? Sharon Squassoni, a global security expert from the Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists, bursts into laughter. It’s not reassuring.“There’s just no comparison, the shift in our nuclear arsenal is astounding. We have a wide range of power and capabilities. We even have bombs where you can dial in the yield before use.”Moreover, the trend towards smaller weapons designed for less indiscriminate destruction doesn’t necessarily make us safer. Seth Baum, executive director of the Global Catastrophic Risk Institute, explains:“In military circles, the overall trend over the years has been away from mass destruction to precision, reducing collateral damage. However, the argument goes that precision actually makes it more likely that we might use them.”New and ever more versatile weapons are now on the horizon, from unpredictable hypersonic delivery systems designed to zig-zag past missile shields, to high-altitude strikes that would disable our electronics and communications networks.For some, the old ways are still the best. The relative simplicity of gun-type devices like Little Boy mean they are perfect for terrorists looking to assemble their own. With the proliferation of nuclear states and lax security in countries of the former Soviet Union, getting fissile material is less a problem than you might think. One Russian prosecutor in a case involving the theft of uranium noted that potatoes were guarded better. There is no reason why a modern-day remake of Little Boy would be any less powerful than the original, says Squassoni. “Of course it would be as powerful as Hiroshima. Little Boy was 15 kilotons – that’s a pretty small bomb.”The hard part has already been done. Creating the bomb was difficult. Recreating it isn’t.In the days afterwards, the explosion is named the ‘pikadon’ by survivors: “flash–bang”. However, those closest to the epicentre insist on calling it simply ‘pika’. They do not remember the boom, only the flare then an eerie silence, a moment of time caught in light like a camera flash.“I remember vividly how a stone lantern in the garden became brilliantly lit,” wrote Dr Hachiya.The atomic bomb uses light as a weapon. It converts matter into energy at the speed of light, and some of its designers had suggested sounding a “super powerful siren” before detonation, to blind anyone who looked up and happened to catch sight of the flash. The survivors were left with an unforgettable image.“That beautiful cloud! Its beauty defies description,” recalled a friend of Dr Hachiya. “I have never seen anything so magnificent in my life!”The doctor noted that “it was at the moment of the birth of this cloud, with its ever-changing colour, that Hiroshima was wiped out. It was at this moment that Hiroshima city, the culmination of many years' work, disappeared with her good citizens into the beautiful sky.”The ‘mushroom cloud’ became the bomb’s own trademark. It had to be seen to be feared. Some Manhattan Project scientists had wanted to stage demonstrations of the weapon for Japanese generals to convince them to surrender, rather than a live bombing. Hiroshima was selected partly because the damage would be “sufficiently spectacular…when publicity on it is released.” This wasn’t just an act of war, it was a media event. “There stood the Enola Gay, bathed in floodlights like the star of a Hollywood movie,” Colonel Tibbetts recalled about boarding the plane. “For the next 20 minutes we were put through a photo routine to which none of us were accustomed.” As they returned to base, tail gunner Bob Caron snapped a picture of the cloud that sprouted behind them. His would be the only official photographs successfully developed from the mission. He wrote to his mother, asking her to collect press clippings for their scrap book.The view was different from the ground.“Many times I tried to trip the shutter release but the victim would ask for pity,” one Japanese photographer said about touring the aftermath. “It was too cruel, too inhuman to ignore their pleadings.”“If I had known it was an atom bomb, I don’t think I would have ever tried taking pictures.”The strike soon developed into an information war. Initial official reports to the Japanese people were that the US had deployed a new, ‘special bomb’, but the damage was minimal. In Hiroshima, what we would now call ‘fake news’ proliferated among the survivors. Some heard that the city would be uninhabitable for 75 years. There were rumours that Japan had secretly developed its own ‘special’ bombs, and had destroyed Los Angeles among other American cities.American wanted the truth to be known, at least for now. Leaflets were dropped on potential further targets featuring Caron’s snapshot. It noted that “the atomic bomb’s horrendous destructive power can be understood by viewing this photo.” An earlier leaflet dropped on Hiroshima had warned civilians that although the targets were military, “unfortunately, bombs have no eyes.”Seventy-five years later the atomic information war is still raging, but has moved from leaflets to social media. The Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists warns of a general poisoning of our ‘information ecosphere’, including “sophisticated, technology-propelled propaganda” and leaders throwing doubt on scientists and “national institutions that have historically provided societal stability and cohesion.” The hacking of Twitter in July, in which accounts including American Democratic nominee Joe Biden sent out spam messages, had dark implications. President Trump, apparently not hacked, once tweeted that he had a “much bigger and more powerful” nuclear button than Kim Jong Un.“I don’t think nuclear war could be started by hacking into Twitter,” says Squassoni, “but when you have the leaders of countries issuing nuclear threats on it, that’s a serious development.”Hiroshima’s after-image faded into the culture of the atomic 20th Century, the ultimate symbol of danger and progress. Children could draw the cloud's silhouette, like Mickey Mouse. It influenced everything from the nuclear-powered rage of Godzilla to the bikini swimsuit, named for nuclear tests on Bikini Atoll in the Marshall Islands.Meanwhile, Hiroshima and its people found themselves transformed into silent symbols. The mushroom cloud. The ruined dome. Kengo Nikawa’s pocket watch, stuck forever at 8.15. And for some, just their shadow, burned into the wall behind them, like a photo negative.9th August 1945. It is a cloudy day in Nagasaki. 40,000 people are blasted into memory. The original target for Fat Man, the second and so far final nuclear bomb used in warfare, was Kokura. It is skipped over due to a thick hanging fog.Meanwhile, Hiroshima is still in the shadow of the first bombing, with many survivors now living in Dr Hachiya’s hospital. A horse, burned and blind, ambles around its garden, eating the leaves of a potato patch the doctor had planted.Eleven days after the blast, more baffling symptoms become evident. People who were relatively unscathed develop speckles on their skin, then die. Another mystery: epilation.“Falling hair! This was an unusual symptom, but undeniable. Unconsciously, I grabbed some of my hair and pulled. I did not have much hair in the first place, but the amount that came out made me feel sick,” wrote Dr Hachiya.No one knows what is happening. They are in the dark.“The idea was to explode the damned thing,” recalled Hymer Friedell, who oversaw biomedical research at the Manhattan Project and later toured Hiroshima. “We weren't terribly concerned with the radiation”The world experts on the subject were now those who lived through it. Dr Hachiya noted that the closer the survivors were to the centre of the blast, the more likely they were to develop these novel symptoms, placing each patient on a map. The value of this data did not go unnoticed.Navy Secretary James Forrestal told President Truman that survivors would offer “a unique opportunity for the study of the medical and biological effects of radiation which is of utmost importance to the United States.” A legion of international scientists descended on Japan and the survivors. Reports from local doctors were collected and expanded upon. The survivors were to be studied, not necessarily treated. A cure was never an option.Many ‘hibakusha’, as they came to be known, found themselves outcasts. Their stories were censored by the American occupation, while they were shunned by society at large.“Every survivor has had a different experience,” says Takuo Takigawa, director of the Hiroshima Peace Memorial Museum. “Some people didn’t want to go near them because they were ‘infected’. With others, there was a thought that they would soon die anyway.”Hibakusha were banned from public baths, for fear of contaminating the water. People refused to employ them, and certainly wouldn't marry one. The spectre of radiation exposure transformed into the idea that they were inherently sullied. Some chose to never have children.“At that time in Japan any physical deformation or injury was heavily shunned,” says Barak Kushner, professor of East Asian history at Cambridge. However, the shame extended even to those without visible injuries. “In some ways they are symbols of Japan’s failure and defeat, and of the poverty to which Japan has sunk, as it’s not able to help them. They don’t get specific compensation until years later.”Meanwhile, studies moved from the immediate aftermath to the long term. By 1950, 130,000 survivors were enrolled in what is known as the ‘Life Span Study’. It precisely surveyed where each survivor was standing relative to the blast, just as Dr Hachiya had done. Surviving hibakusha have reported for check ups right up to today.The study forms the world’s largest bank of knowledge on the effect of radiation on the human body. It is so thorough that in 1982, scientists at the Los Alamos National Lab built a replica of Little Boy – including the uranium – to better understand its findings. It helped develop safe medical uses for radiation, like CAT scans and X-rays. Nasa consulted it to help protect astronauts from cosmic radiation. Now the survey is focussing on the next generation, tracking possible effects on survivors’ children.“The rainy season officially ended yesterday,” Takigawa chuckles. “Today is a very sunny day in Hiroshima.”It is difficult to put a final number on the number killed by the attacks in 1945, given the confusion afterwards and the malignant effects of radiation, but estimates suggest more than 200,000.The rumours that Hiroshima would be uninhabitable for 75 years proved false. Both it and Nagasaki are now thriving. In 1949, a law ordered that Hiroshima be rebuilt as a “Peace Memorial City, a symbol of the ideal of making lasting peace a reality.” Despite fears over radiation, many citizens chose to stay and rebuild the city they loved. Before the war it had a population of around 350,000. Now it’s more than 2 million. The ruin of the industrial museum remains preserved at the centre, the dome cracked and open to the sky.Once forgotten and ignored by the world at large, the hibakusha became figureheads for peace movements worldwide. The Memorial Museum was established at least partly to remind the world that the victims are people, not just symbols.“The hibakusha saw it as a mission of sorts, to tell their story,” says Takigawa. “The reality of what happened, the feelings and memory, must be passed on, so people can feel the horrors of that event themselves.”The threat has not passed, for any of us. Every year since 1947, the Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists, first established by former Manhattan Project workers, set their ‘Doomsday Clock’ to indicate how near we are to annihilation. This year it ticked to 100 seconds to midnight, the closest it has ever been. They point to the breakdown of arms control treaties a general worsening of relations between the great powers and climate change as contributing factors.“The world is sleepwalking its way through a newly unstable nuclear landscape,” the Bulletin warned. “Any belief that the threat of nuclear war has been vanquished is a mirage.”Moreover, nuclear weapons now have to compete with a wide variety of impending disasters.“They’ve fallen out of the public consciousness, but polling 20 somethings shows they actually believe they will be used in the coming decades. The younger generation is very fatalistic. However, nuclear weapons don't rise to the top of the agenda for them, whereas climate really does,” says Squassoni.After 75 years, the light from that blast has faded in the public consciousness. Simply put, we are no longer afraid of the atom bomb. Then again, neither were the people of Hiroshima.Few people live in constant fear of the newer threats Seth Baum specialises in, from artificial intelligence to designer viruses that would make coronavirus balk. They’re threats most will never have imagined, right up until the point they happen.“The last time that happened was the September 11 terrorist attack, which was low-tech, but it caught us off guard and changed how we think about the world,” says Baum. “So did coronavirus.”Takigawa says Hiroshima takes pride in teaching the world a lesson about peace, even though it had to suffer terribly for it. “There may be other ways of learning this lesson, but I can’t think of any,” he notes. In 2016, Barack Obama became the first US president to visit the site of the bombing. He gave a touching speech, paying tributes to the hibakusha and noting that “the scientific revolution that led to the splitting of an atom requires a moral revolution as well.” It’s another admirable lesson, just one of many we’ve learned from Hiroshima and Nagaski: technologically, medically, politically and philosophically.Yet, fundamentally, they’re not lessons the people of Hiroshima needed to learn on 6 August 1945. We can learn from the dead. They can’t learn by dying. All they would ever know is one simple fact: that, in Obama’s words, “on a bright cloudless morning, death fell from the sky, and the world was changed.”We urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: beirut blast missile may have blame says lebanons president
story: Lebanon’s president has suggested that a missile could have been responsible for the catastrophic Beirut blast, as the country’s entrenched ruling class comes under increasing pressure from enraged citizens to resign.In a televised interview on Friday, Michel Aoun rejected calls for an international investigation into the disaster, which killed more than 150 people, saying it could have been caused by “negligence or foreign interference through a missile or bomb”.Experts have discounted the missile theory, pointing out that a fire burning at the port warehouse before the explosion was sufficient to cause the detonation of 2,750 tons of ammonium nitrate that had been stored there.Meanwhile, the head of Hizbollah denied that his powerful Shia militant group had stored arms at the port.“We have nothing in the port: not an arms depot, nor a missile depot, nor missiles, nor rifles, nor bombs, nor bullets, nor nitrate,” Hassan Nasrallah said in a speech broadcast on Friday.Their statements will do little to dissipate public anger, with demonstrations calling for the overthrow of the government expected to be held on Saturday, following clashes between protesters and security forces on Thursday.Several people were injured in the clashes near the parliament building in downtown Beirut, where officers fired tear gas after protesters threw stones at security forces, lit fires and vandalised nearby buildings.Five British medical professionals flew out on Friday to help, after more than 5,000 people were injured in the blast, the Department for International Development said.“The UK is sending these world-leading medics to use their expertise and to make sure the people of Lebanon get the help they need as quickly as possible,” Anne-Marie Trevelyan, the International Development Secretary, said.The UK Government also announced £3 million for the British Red Cross for medical and humanitarian assistance, in addition to an earlier pledge of £5 million.But on the ground in Beirut, the failure of Lebanese leaders to take responsibility for the blast is enraging citizens, who have renewed calls advanced in nationwide protests last year for the entire government to resign.So far, only one member of parliament and the ambassador to Jordan have quit in response to the blast, which many Lebanese say was the result of decades of corruption and mismanagement. Offering her resignation in a televised address on Thursday, Tracy Chamoun, who has served as ambassador since 2017, blamed the disaster on a corrupt political elite in power since the 1975-1990 civil war.“They all must go,” Ms Chamoun said. “This is total negligence.”International leaders are also calling for widespread reform of Lebanon’s governance system. Emmanuel Macron, the French president, told Lebanese citizens who mobbed him during his visit to Beirut on Thursday that international aid would not be passed into “corrupt hands”.Surrounded by demonstrators clamouring for help to oust their reviled leadership, Mr Macron said he was not there to endorse the “regime” but would ask Lebanon’s leaders to accept “a new political deal” and “to change the system”.A rare nationwide protest movement began last October, sparked by an unpopular proposal to tax the WhatsApp messaging app. Demonstrators called for the overthrow of a political oligarchy they accused of enriching itself while hollowing out the state, forcing Saad Hariri to step down as prime minister.Further unrest is expected in the coming days as Lebanese activists have called for “Saturday of Revenge” protests in Beirut this weekend.“We will hang the gallows,” read a message, accompanied by an image of a noose, on one Instagram account with 42,000 followers.“We are anticipating tens of thousands of people to protest in Beirut and other cities in Lebanon on Saturday,” said Joel Gulhane, an analyst with the UK-based Risk Advisory Group.“We are likely to see a return to the earlier days of the protest movement that began in October,” he added. “But the anger and devastation wrought by the explosion, coupled with the sharp decline in quality of life … means that the upcoming period is likely to be more violent than before.”     More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: germans dont worship health service better
story: In judging our Covid-19 performance, we naturally compare it with that of other countries. The most telling comparison is with nations whose predicament is closest to ours. Enormous countries, such as China, Brazil and the US, are not closely comparable. Nor are much poorer countries, or more thinly populated ones.The natural comparisons are Western European, and even here, there are important differences. The Scandinavian countries, with their small, well-extended populations, are not so close to the British experience, although we should learn from their medical systems. The nearest comparisons, surely, are quite densely populated neighbours with roughly similar populations and GDP, urban concentrations and large international airports. That means France, Italy, Germany and, perhaps, Spain.The eventual Covid-19 post-mortem will no doubt unearth mistakes that are uniquely British, but if you look at the story so far, you will see that neither Britain, France, Italy, or Spain has done markedly better than one another. In deaths per million of the population – a more meaningful comparator than total numbers – we, at 684, are the worst of these four but the others are bad too (Italy 582, France 462. Plucky little Belgium, by the way, seems to be the world’s worst, at 851). The only one in a different league is Germany, at 110.Why might this be? First, Germany had the “luck” to get an early case of the coronavirus. A female business traveller from Shanghai arrived on January 16 and fell ill with the virus. She was treated at the Munich Schwabing Hospital. A consequent cluster of 16 cases was identified. On February 13, at the country’s Science Media Centre, a huge press conference reported the scientific findings in detail. The press release warned that “every day the spread is not controlled, the likelihood that the epidemic will develop into a pandemic increases”.But the mere fact of a disease being identified does not mean the authorities know what to do about it. The Germans did. I am no expert on Germany, but here are a few factors.Expertise. The Munich hospital has a special unit for highly contagious life-threatening infections. Its chief physician spoke at the press conference. So did the professor who had developed one of the first tests for Covid-19, as did the president of the Robert Koch Institute in Berlin, the government’s public health institute. Lockdown was quicker than in Britain, but less draconian and more targeted.Testing (mainly for flu) is a more established part of life in Germany than in Britain. It has gone on apace throughout Covid. Also, where the NHS closed down, the normal German health system kept going. Patients with Covid were not, as they were here, told to stay at home unaided. They were constantly monitored. If their oxygen levels dropped too low, they were admitted to hospital. The needs of care homes were not ignored. No patient was sent to a care home unless it could provide 14 days’ quarantine.Media. Far more German journalists are well acquainted with science than are their British counterparts. They give the public clearer facts and fewer scare stories.Dispersal. Unlike Britain, Germany is a country of many different centres, with associated airports – Berlin, Munich, Cologne, Frankfurt and so on, rather than London, London and more London. So there was less danger of a sudden explosion of the plague.A related fact is that the country is federal. Sixteen states, rather than the central government, are responsible for most aspects of health care. This sometimes slows things down, but it also means that, compared with Britain, there is more local “buy-in”, more local players who get going, rather than waiting upon a distant bureaucracy.This creates a good spread of service across Germany. There were plenty of labs for testing, for example, in plenty of places. There was no appalling rush. When Britain finally got round to test and trace, the Government commissioned Serco to run it from a single call centre in Scotland. As the former health secretary, Jeremy Hunt, points out, you are more likely to comply with tracing from a knowledgeable employee of your county council than a call from a student hundreds of miles away. In Germany, the “corona-detectors” are a respected body of local experts.Good politics. Many in Britain have grown rather fed up with the German Chancellor, Angela Merkel, what with her ambiguous speeches and her hostility to Brexit. Her star has gradually waned even at home. Nevertheless, she is a scientist by training and an experienced, steady person. She can command respect in the crisis, precisely because she is not, in any detailed sense, in charge of Covid policy. Rather than having to pretend she has all the answers, she can exercise moral authority.Mrs Merkel is in this enviable position because – astonishing to British eyes – she runs a country in which health care is not usually high on the list of political controversies. In Britain, the health secretary – currently Matt Hancock – has to run all hospitals and the fifth largest workforce in the world. At the same time, he has to spend days in the House of Commons being assailed by accusations that he is trying to “sell off” the NHS and similar nonsense. The German health minister (an able man called Jens Spahn) has infinitely less power, but – no offence to Mr Hancock – can do more practical good. His role has not been to try to run a vast, unmanageable empire, but simply to oil the wheels of a system which already works, by putting in more government money – covering the costs of testing, and paying for ICU beds to be kept available.Why is Germany free of what Mr Hunt calls “the political poison” of our system? Not because Germans don’t care about health – they actually spend a higher proportion of their GDP on it than we do, and they have better health outcomes. It is because they have never bought the doctrine that a particular health care system is sacred.The origins of good health care for ordinary Germans lie in mutual funds in the 19th century, set up to help pay for funerals. These developed into much more sophisticated, competing systems of health insurance, underwritten by the state, but not run by it. Employer and employee both contribute. An unemployed person has his health care paid for in his unemployment insurance. Almost no German citizen falls through the net.The providers are also various. Government-run hospitals are outnumbered by privately run ones and others run by charities (many, for instance by the Order of St John). Because the money follows the patient, the providers have good incentives to provide. Indeed, the problem in Germany is too many hospital beds.In Britain, the health service is an object of high emotion. Behind the praise often lies a fear that it is precarious. In Germany, there is little emotional commitment to the service – rather as, here, there is little intense feeling for Sainsbury’s or Waitrose. Instead of high emotion, there is a high level of confidence. This may help explain why so many more Germans than British have returned to work, although Covid numbers jump upwards from time to time. Psychologically and medically, the German way is better for the national health than is the thing we call the National Health Service.Do you agree that the German health service is better than the NHS? Are there other factors to consider? title: new magaluf lake district became go to destination party loving
story: While Brits behaving badly abroad is nothing new, in the summer of Covid-19 it seems our chickens have come home to roost. Ally Kohler, the director for conservation and communities at Dartmoor National Park Authority, visited the site a week or so ago and was reduced to tears by what she encountered – rubbish strewn across the moor, 50 or so fire pits potentially made out of stones taken from archaeological sites nearby, and every gorse bush used as a makeshift toilet. I used to take my family to this site to picnic, and there is no way I would take them now, she says. If you played hide and seek in the bushes, you can be absolutely assured you would come across soiled toilet tissue - if not worse. We seem to have got into generations of visitors now with no awareness of the countryside code, he says. There is a lack of appreciation that they are in someone's community, and even if they are in open countryside that belongs to somebody, they should respect everything that is there.Chris Higgins, the leader of the Keswick mountain rescue team, says the family had been warned by the bike hire shop that the weather was looking bad but they ignored the advice and set off in thin lycra and windproofs with no indication of which route they were planning. They eventually emerged the following morning, having spent a night on the fells and being forced to abandon their bikes.To be quite blunt they were lucky to have come off as lightly as they did and nobody to be seriously ill or dead, Higgins says.In the past nine days, the mountain rescue team has received 12 call-outs – a 50 per cent increase on previous years. We totally understand how people want to get out into countryside, but a lot don't appreciate the seriousness of their undertaking, he says.The fear among people in the Lakes is that this year's staycation antics will put off the sort of tourists upon whom the livelihood of its communities depend.If people come expecting Wordsworth and encounter a scene befitting Wandsworth, the worry is that they may never return.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: sandhurst sees surge applications downturn jobs market sends
story: Sandhurst has seen a surge in applications this year as the former head of the army said a downturn in the jobs market has made more graduates consider serving with the British Army. The Daily  understands that applications for officer entry at the Royal Military Academy rose by 62 per cent compared to last year, with overall applications for soldiers and officers combined up by 32 per cent.  General Lord Dannatt, former chief of the general staff, told this newspaper that it was not “surprising” applications had risen in the year the world comes to terms with the coronavirus pandemic.  “The fact there is a 62 per cent increase is largely down to a lot of young people leaving university, majority are graduates, they'll have looked at career possibilities and realised the army is a good option when other opportunities aren't looking promising, I'm not surprised,” Lord Dannatt said. “We know a lot of businesses will struggle once the furlough scheme ends and there will be a reduced number of jobs for graduates in the labour market, but the Army always needs a healthy intake of qualified people so why wouldn't they apply? A year developing your leadership skills is something special.” It comes as Sandhurst prepares to host its first ever virtual insight day next week. An army source said that the event, which will be held on Zoom on August 12, looks set to have 1000 potential recruits logging on to join in a live tour of the gym and speak to serving officers about life at the academy, as well as commanders. The last physical insight day Sandhurst held had 560 people attend, of which 358 were potential recruits and 202 parents and s. “This year we expect to hit the 1,000 people limit on the virtual insight day,” the source added.“They may also have mums and dads sat around the laptop with them, so this figure is quite incredible. It shows how we are adapting to the covid challenge.” More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: confusing contradictory data triggering pointless local lockdowns
story: A kind of data fever is gripping Britain, with numerous institutions pushing out daily surveillance reports, analyses, models and projections, in an attempt to get a handle on the pandemic. If it all seems baffling and uncoordinated, then that’s because it is. Estimates between groups vary widely, and government policy appears to be driven by the flimsiest of results.After a northern lockdown was imposed, chief medical officer Chris Whitty warned that Britain may have reached the limits of lifting restrictions, leading to fears that pubs and shops may have to shut so schools can reopen in September.But what is the data actually showing and how reliable is it?Take the weekly pilot infection survey’ results from the Office for National Statistics (ONS) that prompted Boris Johnson to bring in new restrictions in the north west at the beginning of August.The ONS estimated that 35,700 people in England were infected with Covid-19 between July 20 and July 26, or 1 in 1,500 people. The week before statisticians had calculated about 27,700 were infected, or about 1 in 2,000. Warning lights flashed and widespread hand-wringing commenced.However, the new calculation was based on just 59 people testing positive out of a six weekly total of 116,026 swab tests. The previous week just 45 people tested positive out of a running total of 114,674. So just 14 extra positive tests had triggered mass panic.Oddly enough, when the figures fell to 1,100 in June, journalists were told to ignore it as a data blip, and we have been regularly warned that determining infection rates on such low ONS numbers is fraught with difficulty. This time, however, the ONS said it suggest a slight increase.“When ONS  stated ‘suggests’ it’s a signal something doesn’t add up,” said one Oxford academic.Unsurprisingly, the hugely erratic figures swung back the other way on Friday, with the ONS estimating that 1 in 1,900 people are now infected, or 28,300 in total - 3,700 new cases a day.Again, though, it was based on just 53 people testing positive, so just six people fewer than the previous week. Hardly a conclusive finding. Meanwhile the King’s College app, which has been tracking symptoms from March and now has 3.5 million users, paints a much more optimistic picture. The data set is the largest out there and now includes swab testing. Yet its estimates have consistently been lower than most. The app estimates there are about 26,500 infections in the whole of the UK, and 1,439 new cases per day in England - nearly three times lower than the ONS figures than prompted northern lockdown. King's researchers believe that cases have been stable for several weeks with no evidence of a second wave.Nowcasting by Public Health England (PHE) and the University of Cambridge also suggests cases are flatlining, or possibly falling slightly. But it is not just surveillance data that is muddying the waters. Trying to establish trends from the number of people testing positive for coronavirus is also bedevilled with problems. The decision to lockdown in the north was also based on community and healthcare testing that appeared to be trending upwards.Through July, testing showed a rise from about 500 cases a day to 750. However when picked apart, it became clear that Pillar 2 (tests in the community) were trending up while Pillar 1 (tests in healthcare settings) were trending down.While more cases in the community might seem problematic, there was no equivalent rise in hospital admissions or death rates, suggesting it was mild cases that were being spotted. The number of very sick people continues to fall so the NHS is in no danger of being overwhelmed.Look a bit more closely at the Pillar 1 rise and it becomes clear that the increase may actually be a result of more testing. Between July 1 and July 31, the seven-day moving average for Pillar 1 tests jumped by 20 per cent and Pillar 2 by 82 per cent. When the rise in positive tests is mapped against the rise in testing, Pillar 2 is shown as flatlining and Pillar 1 declines a little more sharply.Test, track and trace is also likely to be skewing the figures, particularly in hotspots like Leicester.It stands to reason that testing people who have been in contact with those known to be infected will find more infections. That’s the whole point after all. It will pick up those who did not even know they have the disease and would never have been tested normally. It should be possible to account for this bias, but it is not being done.It is also unclear how reliable the government’s figures are. On July 28, Pillar 1 reported 64 cases and Pillar 2 512 cases - 576 in total,  yet the government website reported a total of 547. In May, it emerged that tens of thousands of cases had been double counted, and it appears that it is still a problem. When local lockdowns are being determined on low numbers to begin with, a missing 29 cases-a-day really matters. Overall there seems to be no evidence of a second wave. Figures out from Imperial this week suggested cases had continued to fall after the easing of lockdown restrictions. One in two hospital trusts have not reported a death in the past seven days and three quarters have not seen a death in the past 48 hours. Despite differences in daily rates, all groups seem to agree that about 8 people in 10,000 are infected and the R rate is unlikely to be above 1 for England. Professor Karol Sikora, dean of medicine at the University of Buckingham, said: “At the peak there were around 3,000 coroanvirus patients admitted to hospital in England. The number is now around 60. There are 694 patients in hospital, down from 17,000. These are huge drops, and most importantly, they are continuing to fall.”More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: heatwave continue next week beaches brace another day tourists
story: The heatwave currently sweeping the UK is due to continue towards the end of next week, as the country's beaches brace themselves for another wave of day-trippers.Temperatures are expected to hit over 30 degrees over the weekend and well into next week, particularly in the South, according to the Met Office.Yesterday Heathrow and Kew Gardens reached a high of 36.4 degrees - making it the hottest day in August since 2003, and the fifth hottest on record.In Bournemouth, visitors were said to have arrived at the beach as early as 3am to bag the best spots.As many as 70 coastguard callouts were made before midday as thousands headed to the coast to make the most of Britain's beaches.This included 14,000 people packed on the sandy beach at Perranporth in Cornwall where 15 rescues launched were launched.The RNLI yesterday warned about the dangers of inflatable paddle boards and kayaks being used on the UK's holiday hotspots.Steve Instance, the South West sea safety lead with the charity, said: Inflatable stand up paddle boards and kayaks can be taken by the tide and wind very, very easily.People can fall off them and get separated. Once separated catching up with them is really difficult.Despite problems with social distancing, he urged tourists and locals to go to lifeguarded beaches.Today areas of the North of England will see average temperatures while the heat may rise as high as 36 across southeast England.Following the hot and humid weather, the Met Office has already issued a yellow warning for possibly torrential rain which could develop in several areas of the country on Monday and Tuesday.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: need scalpel government has covid sledgehammer
story: The Government’s sledgehammer approach to Covid-19 shows a lack of faith in their £10 billion test-and-trace regime. We were promised a “world-beating” system to identify local outbreaks and enable less disruptive interventions: small numbers isolating, closing inidual schools and workplaces, or, at worst, locking down a street or borough. This was supposed to mimic South Korea: the nation of 51 million which avoided a national lockdown thanks to mass testing and tracing.The UK not only had a first lockdown but the new measures being introduced are increasingly broad. Two in five people in the North West are now under household restrictions – despite few confirmed cases in many localities. People returning from entire countries, rather than just affected regions, are required to self-isolate. Boris Johnson has warned of the risk of a second wave “within two weeks”, a shocking admission. If testing and tracing were working, none of this would be happening.At present, not enough people are coming forward for testing and there are serious deficiencies in identifying contacts. The Government’s testing regime found just 5,300 of 35,700 estimated cases identified by the Office for National Statistics between July 27 and August 2. The latest weekly tracing statistics are also worrying: almost half of the friends and family of iniduals who test positive are not being reached. We also have no idea whether people are complying with requests to isolate. “It’s a bit of a half-arsed system – it kinda works, but not really,” Professor Christina Pagel of University College London concludes.It’s time for a serious rethink. To start, the Government must learn the lesson from the failure of Public Health England’s highly centralised testing regime. Even after the department took control in April, it refused to decentralise responsibilities. Instead, it built a small number of large lighthouse labs and created ineffective national tracing call centres.This centralisation has hamstrung the entire system. Tests take precious days too long to be sent, returned and processed. Care homes that could have used local laboratories were instead left without tests after issues with Randox kits. Smaller labs that could provide speedy results locally have been rebuffed. Local health officials until recently lacked the necessary data to combat outbreaks in their area.By contrast, in Wales – after the Welsh Government botched testing for months – local authorities and hospitals are testing and tracing at the regional level. They have proven relatively agile in responding to local outbreaks. Even in England local authorities such as Blackburn with Darwen council in Lancashire and Sandwell in the West Midlands have given up on the national scheme, set up their own systems and begun knocking on the doors of people who do not return phone calls. Local health teams, who are responsible for dealing with outbreak clusters in schools and workplaces, are successfully reaching 98 per cent of contacts.There is a need for far wider testing. Tests should be offered to people who are asked to isolate – because of travel or contact with a positive case. This would help identify chains of transmission and allow people to cease isolating sooner. The Government claims to have a daily testing capacity of over 335,000, but is testing closer to 175,000 per day. Even this isn’t enough. To find all the cases, we need to mass test millions of people every week. This could be done using new rapid‑testing technologies from the likes of DnaNudge and LamPORE.We also need bigger carrots and sticks to encourage people to get tested and isolate. People are not handing over the names of contacts to avoid putting friends and family in a difficult situation. The average number of contacts provided to tracers is down to two and a half, a decline of 64 per cent since the scheme began. If you have been social enough to get coronavirus, you have probably socialised with more than a couple of people. People may also be refusing to pick up the dreaded “0300” call that will tell you to isolate for 14 days.Payments, and perhaps even fines for non-compliance, would encourage people to get tested and isolate. This would be far less expensive and draconian than spreading coronavirus and a second lockdown. Australians can receive £1,100 for isolation if they do not receive other payments, and can even get £230 while isolating awaiting a test result in Victoria. Payments are combined with large fines – up to £11,100 – for people who break self-isolation orders.The definition of madness is doing the same thing twice, but expecting a different result. A second bout of inadequate testing and tracing will lead to another outbreak and lockdown. This would not only be catastrophic for our physical, mental and economic wellbeing, but also politically disastrous. The public may forgive the first outbreak they are unlikely to forgive a second.Matthew Lesh is the head of research at the Adam Smith InstituteMore from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: portugal insurance demand soars britons ignore fco advice
story: Portugal remains on the FCO&#39s &#39red list&#39, but Britons are going anywayUK tourists ‘left in dark’ by holiday quarantine, say MPs How to get travel insurance should you choose to ignore Foreign Office adviceSign up to the  Travel newsletterThere has been absolutely overwhelming demand for an insurance package launched by Portugal's National Tourism Authority that offers cover for foreign visitors.Given the FCO still advises against all but essential travel to Portugal, the main barrier for UK holidaymakers is the difficulty in securing insurance for their trip.But this initiative, run by a Madeira-based business, offers cover that includes medical hospital expenses “associated” with Covid-19, as well as protection against cancellations or holiday interruptions, starting at €37.20 (£33.62).Marco Pyta, commercial director for the company, Bónus Seguros, told Portugal Resident on Friday: “By midday today, I think we had received over 1,000 calls. Yesterday there were 800. We had no idea this insurance would be so popular”. Pyta has had to bring in a special task force to cope with the “unbelievable” number of enquiries. “Nintey per cent have come from England,” he says. “It’s as if everyone there wants to come on holiday to Portugal.”Scroll down for more news updates.Mustique is among the first in the Caribbean to be welcoming guests back this summer - as long as you're armed with proof of a negative Covid-19 PCR antigen test carried out at an accredited laboratory 72 hours or fewer before you fly. Just 100 miles west of Barbados, Mustique, a favourite among the Royals, is today home to around 100 fabulous villas, along with two charming boutique hotels, immaculately kept white-sand beaches, a sweet little library and thriving equestrian centre.Nigel Tisdall delves into its fascinating history. Welcome to paradiseHosting doesn't come naturally to Anna Hart, but she's had to master the art this summer as she opens her home in Margate to many a visitor.Here are her top dos and don'ts.Nick Gibb insists schools will be safe to return to in England come September, and says dangerous infection rates abroad are constantly monitored to help the government take decisions on quarantine for travellers.I’m not religious, says Sarah Baxter. Nor are many of those sparking the rise in popularity of pilgrimages. Such is the trend that the Association of English Cathedrals decreed 2020 the Year of Cathedrals and Pilgrimage. At times of crisis, people want to reset and find a new path no wonder pilgrimage – secular or otherwise – feels apt right now.The 55-mile Glastonbury Water Way was created this year by the British Pilgrimage Trust, an organisation hoping to revive the tradition of walking to sacred places. Starting at the Thermae Bath Spa, the route is a mobile cleanse via natural water sources and churches, connecting walkers to both the land and those who have trodden it before. Read Sarah's verdict of the route, and a selection of other great options, here.Some worrying news from the Czech Republic, which has recorded its biggest daily rise in new coronavirus cases since April 3, the health ministry reported today.The central European country of 10.7 million recorded 323 new cases yesterday, bringing the total number of cases detected to 18,060. Of those, 12,749 have 'recovered' and 389 have died of Covid-19.Health officials have said the recent uptick in cases is due to local clusters and they say hospitalisations, at 116, are well below peaks of over 400 as the government seek to avoid a national lockdown again.However, officials have cautioned that some measures taken to curb the illness are likely to return after the summer holidays when cities become more crowded again and the flu season arrives.The rising number of cases in the Czech Republic prompted Norway this week to re-impose a 10-day quarantine for travellers from the country.Seven safer destinations for a last-minute summer holidayAn absence of other tourists was a recurring theme on Sasha Vasilyuk's trip to Molise, Italy’s second smallest region, just above Puglia.Despite its historical riches and pristine landscapes, including Pietrabbondante and Saepinum, one of the best-preserved ancient Roman ruins in Italy, it is so unknown that Italians like to joke that “Molise doesn’t exist” (it rhymes in Italian).  She writes:In today’s climate, a lack of visitors is a big plus. This under-the-radar region has become one of the safest choices for Britons eager for an Italian vacation (as of Thursday, it had recorded eight cases in the previous seven days 3 per 100,000). In fact, some lucky travellers have secured a free stay in Molise this summer – in San Giovanni in Galdo, one of its many picturesque villages.Read the rest of the piece here.As of today the face mask rule has been extended in England - meaning coverings are now mandatory in the following:Indoor places of worshipMuseums and galleries Public areas in hotels and hostelsIt comes as figures from the Office for National Statistics suggest that face masks are the new normal in Britain - with 96 per cent of people wearing one to leave the house.The survey, which takes in the period from July 29 to August 2, found that 96 per cent of adults who had left their homes said they had worn a face covering to slow the spread of coronavirus – up from 84 per cent last week and 71 per cent the week before that.Gabriella Swirling reports on the ONS figures here. The Natural History Museum in London reopened this weekGatwick Airport's South Terminal could remain shut until next summer, bosses warned, as British Airways launched a wave of job cuts.The country's second-largest airport this week told staff that one of its two terminals may not reopen for a year and redundancies are likely after hopes of a recovery were crushed by new travel restrictions.In a live-streamed town hall meeting with staff on Monday, chief executive Stewart Wingate said the South Terminal cannot return to full operations until carriers' schedules are restored, employees said.It came as BA began telling thousands of its workers whether they will lose their jobs in a wave of brutal cutbacks.Oliver Gill and Louis Ashworth have the full story.A melting glacier is at risk of breaking apart due to a heatwave, forcing the evacuation of part of an Italian alpine valley, reports Reuters.The alarm was raised on Wednesday when experts in helicopters realised that the Planpincieux glacier, at an altitude of about 2,800 metres in the Ferret Valley in the Mont Blanc massif, was slipping dangerously.A heatwave has created a layer of water under the glacier, which is roughly the size of the Milan cathedral, making it more prone to a break.A photo taken from a helicopter on Friday of the Planpincieux glacierAbout 75 residents and tourists in homes or hotels in hamlets in the threatened part of the valley were evacuated and police threw up roadblocks to prevent others from entering.“The season was going well despite the COVID pandemic,” Jacopo Nitri, who owns a small hotel in the area, told the Corriere. “I had to send away 25 clients and cancel some reservations. If the situation is not resolved in the next few days it will be a disaster.”The Lake District has seen a transformation of late, and it's not pretty, reports Joe Shute.While dependent on visitor income for their livelihood – Cumbria's tourist economy is worth nearly £3 billion to the county each year – currently, the sheer number of tourists and the lack of respect they are showing for the countryside is driving locals to the brink.Jon Watson has farmed his land 18 years and runs a self-catering accommodation business, and says of the antisocial behaviour he is encountering on the fells:It's twice as bad at least, if not more, than previous years. There is a certain element who normally would have gone to Spain or somewhere like that, or a festival, where they are used to leaving rubbish behind, but now they are coming here because there is nowhere else to go.Read the full report here.Visitors in and around GrasmereBelgium is officially off the FCO’s ‘green list’, meaning anyone arriving into the UK from the country, as of today, will have to self-isolate for 14 days. However, there is an exception for travellers who drive through Belgium, as many do from Germany and the Netherlands, to reach the UK via France.Provided the car makes no stops during the entire journey within Belgium, no passengers get out and no new passengers get in, then the occupants of the car will not need to quarantine upon their arrival into the UK, the Department for Transport has confirmed.Read the full guide here.Holidaymakers are being “left in the dark” by a “grossly unfair” lack of transparency on quarantine restrictions, MPs have warned as fears France will be placed on the Government's red list led some to cancel their trips.In the latest blow to summer breaks, rising cases in the country have sparked concerns it will be added to the list of destinations requiring holidaymakers to quarantine for 14 days on their return to Britain, following the addition of Belgium, Andorra and the Bahamas from Saturday and Spain at the end of last month.  If such restrictions were brought in, an estimated million British travellers could be affected, with around half a million believed to already be in the country and a similar number set to head to France before the end of the month.Read the full report, by Sam Meadows, Charles Hymas and David Chazan.A recap of the top stories:French quarantine considered by ministers as infections riseChancellor says UK Government will not hesitate to expand quarantine listDutch Prime Minister urges tourists to avoid Amsterdam's busiest areasJapan records record number of coronavirus casesBritons asked to stay away from busiest beaches as heatwave beginsCoronavirus latest news:  Preston warns young people not to &#39kill granny&#39 as data shows almost half of new cases are in under 30sWatch: bride and groom caught in Beirut blast during video shootComment: We intend to return as many illegal migrants who have arrived as possibleConfusing and contradictory data is triggering pointless local lockdowns Heatwave to continue into next week as beaches brace for another day of touristsChildren&#39s author shot in his own home diesMillionairess accused of trying to school standards stand the testA-level and GCSE results 2020: how will grades be calculated without exams?Left-Handers Day 2020: the history behind the celebration and 13 facts about the wonderful title: sorry boris lifting weights wont get us
story: Have the confidence to go back to work! Power up the economy! Wave some dumbbells around your local gym while wearing a suit! All messages relayed in recent days by the Prime Minister, who appears confused by the fact that, after months of government-decreed inertia, people aren’t rushing to get on board with his hasty about-turn.Like much of their response to this pandemic, this sudden acknowledgement that we need to once again engage with life beyond our front doors is too little, too late. For after months of being told that the outside world is a war zone, that all but essential trips are tantamount to a death sentence for the vulnerable, that those who really care must stay in, mask up and shut up, is it any wonder the messaging has stuck?Boris Johnson, Rishi Sunak et al might think a few cheesy photo opportunities can unpick the agoraphobia rendering parts of England a ghost island, but they would do far better to accept this current crisis of confidence is one of their own creation. Explaining how and why it is now safe to stop heeding the months’ worth of red flags they have been waving – rather than telling people to get into waters that were apparently shark-infested just moments ago – would surely be a smoother means of managing this period.The initial messaging had to be strident, that much is true – by March 23, we were in a sorrier state than most of Europe. But Johnson is wrong if he thinks that spending a third of the year hammering that same mantra – stay home – can be wiped from the public consciousness by gurning near a treadmill.Over the months of lockdown, we learned to live entirely (or close to it) within our own four walls. Unlearning that now requires as much gusto as the efforts that went into enforcing the shutdown in the first place.The toll – not virus deaths, but the myriad other kinds – is growing clearer. And among it is the damage caused to our cities, and the lives of those who reside there. People choose metropolitan areas to live a life that is out, not in one that is powered by Saturday afternoon football matches and Wednesday night pub trips and Friday evenings at the theatre the quick coffees and dinners and post-work drinks and gym class catch-ups. Cities often feel like spaghetti, where “your people” are in disparate pockets, not your own home. No wonder then that in mid-March, with lockdown looming, a quarter of a million people fled London knowing that without people and places and things, little would be left.They were right then, and continue to be. In the month since “Super Saturday”, when restaurants, pubs and hairdressers were allowed to reopen, the capital has felt flat flatter, perhaps, in the knowledge that more of life as we knew it is back with us, but people are no longer interested. Restaurants usually booked out months ahead lie half empty on Saturday nights Soho is deserted, ditto Camden, Victoria, take your pick – we have gone from sardines to tumbleweed. It’s unsettling and deeply sad, to see hubs (of which the capital is just one) turned – financially, culturally, socially – to dust.The Government is worried about the effects of our continued staying home – economically speaking, at least. But while initiatives like Eat Out to Help Out are welcome, restaurants showing signs of life on Monday and Wednesday for one month of the year is simply not enough. Lockdown taught us to trade full social calendars for empty ones now, instead of reasoning why you would stay in, the question is why would you go out? There have been so many rules and so many changes the first three months in which nothing whatsoever was allowed were surely easier, or less prone to causing headaches over what configuration of social activity won’t get you in trouble.The adage goes that it takes 12 weeks – or the length of the first portion of our lockdown – for habits to become ingrained. Either way, they have. And £10 off dinner on a Monday night won’t be enough to change that.Soothing national malaise is currently a global conundrum. And so it has fallen to Caesar McCool, “the no drama llama”, to calm strife in Portland, Oregon, which is edging towards its 70th day of protests over police brutality. Whether a retired six-year-old Argentine champion camelid can resolve institutionalised racism is anyone’s guess, but the 350lb emotional support animal (who resides at the Mystic Llama Farm, obviously) has been a source of solace in recent months, offering hugs to protesters and photos for fans, of whom there are now more than 10,000 on Instagram.“There’s a lightness in the air when he’s around, and that’s what people especially need right now,” one explained. Nobody was expecting a pandemic, certainly, but a llamactivist? This year has had its share of twists, if nothing else.There is some optimism this side of the Atlantic, too – at least for one couple, who described their engagement via candlelit proposal as “an unforgettable day.” In spite of the fact it burned their Sheffield flat down. All credit to Albert Ndreu for his efforts – a surprise of 100 tea lights spelling out “Marry me?” and 60 balloons secretly adorning their studio – a drama elevated (and later fumigated) when his partner returned to plumes of black smoke coming from the front door. Three fire crews were called the couple are now living with Mr Ndreu’s cousin.Not the most auspicious start for the future, a cynic might think. But – assuming it’s not the fumes talking – surmising the event that turned their home into an ashtray as the “most beautiful” day of their lives is a kind of positivity worthy of admiration. Even if the insurers disagree.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Special postponed yet again as America’s coronavirus cases continue to climbJennifer Aniston has reacted to news of the long-awaited Friends reunion being delayed yet again, saying she is “very sad” it’s been postponed.The unscripted HBO Max special was originally scheduled to shoot mid-March. When productions were shut down due to the coronavirus pandemic, it was then pushed back to May, and then again to August.On Friday (7 August), it was announced the special would be delayed again as America’s grim death rate continues to accelerate.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesSpeaking about the new delay, Aniston told Deadline: “Unfortunately it’s very sad that we had to move it again. It was, ‘How do we do this with live audiences?’ This is not a safe time. Period. That’s the bottom line. It’s not a safe time to do it.”She added: “It’s going to be super. You know what? This has also given us more time to make it even more exciting and more fun than it would have been. So I choose to see it as the glass is half-full that it got postponed. Look, we’re not going anywhere. You’re never going to get rid of Friends, sorry. You’re stuck with us for life guys.”Timothy Dalton: ‘Why do we need to offer people gratuitous sex?’Friends star Jennifer Aniston describes struggle to ‘escape’ RachelLisa Kudrow says Friends left her with ‘commitment issue’Aniston will be joined by fellow Friends stars Courteney Cox, Lisa Kudrow, David Schwimmer, Matt LeBlanc and Matthew Perry in the special.It will mark the first time that all six stars are reunited in front of the cameras. title: ae weiwei help the hungry campaign auction tracey emin sotherbys
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Sotheby’s sale raising&nbspfunds for food surplus charity The Felix Project will also feature&nbspwork by Tracey&nbspEmin,&nbspBridget Riley&nbspand&nbspAnish&nbspKapoorArtworks by Ai Weiwei, Tracey Emin and Anish Kapoor are among those to be featured in a Sotheby’s contemporary art auction next week to support The Independent’s Help The Hungry campaign.The sale, part of Sotheby’s Contemporary Art Day Auction that runs from 20 to 30 July, includes leading contemporary artists Bridget Riley, Mark Wallinger and Bob and Roberta Smith. All money raised from the auction will go to The Independent’s appeal partner, The Felix Project, London’s largest food surplus distribution charity. Our campaign has so far raised £7.5m towards our £10m goal which includes a pledge to open London’s largest community kitchen to tackle food poverty.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesHighlights from the Sotheby’s Help the Hungry auction include a drawing from Tracey Emin, a series of three etchings by Anish Kapoor, Mark Wallinger’s “Ghost”, and Bob &amp Roberta Smith’s “We Have Only Got Each Other” placard.British-Nigerian artist Yinka Shonibare also joins the catalogue with his “Unstructured Icons - Aristocrat I” alongside a pair of polished steel reliefs by Michael Craig-Martin and a floral plate by Chinese artist Ai Weiwei.   How to support our campaignSotheby’s senior director Oliver Barker said: “We are grateful to the artists who have generously contributed their works and we’re looking forward to channelling part of the excitement of our major sales in London this month into a cause which will provide food and comfort to the capital’s most vulnerable.”  Evgeny Lebedev, proprietor of The Independent, said: “We are delighted to be raising money with Sotheby’s and some of the world’s leading contemporary artists to help build London’s biggest community kitchen that will continue to feed those in need for years to come.”The Felix Project distributes nutritious food that would otherwise go to waste to 350 frontline charities, schools and holiday programmes in London.Founder Justin Byam Shaw said: “Although our food is surplus and donated to us and we have over 1,500 volunteers, our costs are still spiralling. “The coming unemployment crisis means we are in this for the long term. This new community kitchen will provide a high-quality meal for homeless Londoners, cooked by great chefs using surplus food.” Turner Prize-winning artist Mark Wallinger said: “I am delighted to contribute to help raise funds for The Felix Project, a fantastic charity that does such vital work in providing food for vulnerable people throughout London, work that is ever more necessary in our current crisis.”Sotheby’s Help The Hungry Auction will go live on 20 July and will run until 30 July.Help the hungry&nbsp|&nbspNo hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: coronavirus uk new cases infection rates
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Several new hotspots appear to be emerging in areas throughout the countryCoronavirus cases are once again on the rise in the UK, climbing to their highest level since late June.Daily new cases reached above 900 this week, having briefly fallen below 500 in July, with several areas experiencing large spikes in infections.The outbreaks prompted the government to reintroduce restrictions in Greater Manchester, east Lancashire and parts of West Yorkshire in late July.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesThe latest figures from Public Health England reveal that several other areas around the country are also seeing a surge in new cases, according to The Independent‘s analysis.Swindon has seen 55 new Covid-19 cases per 100,000 inhabitants over the last seven days – more than some areas where containment measures are currently in place. Swindon is now the fourth worst affected area in the UK when measured as a proportion of population, having seen a 200 per cent increase in new cases over the last seven days.It has nearly as many new cases per person as Leicester, which was the first place to see tougher local restrictions put in place after the nationwide lockdown lifted.The UK as a whole remains a long way off its peak levels from April and May, when daily new cases frequently reached above 5,000.Yet local spikes could see the recent upwards trend continue if not brought under control, as has been the case in other countries like France and Spain.Having endured a big surge in cases during the early stages of the pandemic, London has since seen its number of daily cases drop at an even greater rate than the rest of the country.No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: help the hungry campaign artwork auction ai weiwei tracey emin
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.&nbspWorks by Ai Weiwei, Tracey Emin and Bridget Riley feature in Sotheby’s sale for food surplus charity The Felix Project “We have only got each other.” What could be more true? At a time when Londoners from all walks of life are struggling due to the impact of coronavirus, the importance of love and care from others has been magnified tenfold.The phrase comes from a work made by the artist Bob &amp Roberta Smith – one of several fantastic lots in an auction kicking off today at sothebys to support The Independent’s Help the Hungry appeal.Over the past four months we have raised more than £7.5m for food redistribution charity The Felix Project – a cause for which we have pledged to raise £10m as well as to open central London’s largest community kitchen.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesThe auction is an opportunity to get your hands on works by some amazing artists – more likely to be seen on the walls of a museum than your living room. They can also be viewed at Sotheby’s, 34-35 New Bond Street.Ceramic has been a recurring motif for Ai Weiwei (a 1995 series of photographs showed him dropping a Han dynasty urn) and he has often used porcelain, for centuries a secret formula known only to Chinese makers. Flowers, too, are significant – when his passport was taken Ai put a bunch of fresh flowers in a bike basket outside his studio every day until he was able to travel freely. This small plate holds a great deal of meaning.Yinka Shonibare deconstructions of icons of western power couldn’t be more current. This elegant woodcut print, using vivid Batik textiles, transposes animal masks from Mali onto the faces of English aristocratic figures enriched off the back of colonisation and slavery. The patterns of textiles overlay the repeating patterns of power and show how history’s long fingers reach into our present.Unfailingly optimistic, Bob &amp Roberta Smith’s work is always a call to care. He’s known for his colourful and impassioned but peaceful slogans (“Make Art Not War” seems like a good standard to live by) and his advocacy of art as a tool for education and understanding. We Have Only Got Each Other quotes his late mother, the artist Deirdre Borlase, spoken in response to the isions revealed during the Brexit campaign — but its universal meaning is clear.I’m a sucker for a good drawing – I’ve always felt that even at 500-odd years distance, it’s the form that brings you closest to an artist the sweep of a human hand that has just left the page. After many years of deeply mining her own emotions and experiences in her work, Emin is an artist at the height of her powers. Her raw, almost agonisingly expressive draughtsmanship gets me every time and this little sketch nails the feeling of having a really good cry.These three etchings – a supremely generous donation from Anish Kapoor, more usually known for the interactive theatricality of his large-scale sculptures – exude a quiet drama. Their simplicity belies their seductiveness velvety and intense, they draw you in, never quite revealing their secrets.No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by emailHow to support our campaignA chance to nab an otherwise sold-out edition (produced for Wallinger’s Whitechapel Gallery show in 2001): Wallinger’s screenprint was created by producing a black-and-white negative of George Stubbs’s painting Whistlejacket, with the addition of a narwhal’s horn, resulting in an image that reminds me of those 19th century fakery-photos of “fairies”. Wallinger was inspired by X-rays of Old Masters, which he thinks of as akin to spirit photography: “The revelation of the invisible, supernatural life of a painting.”A reminder of the pre-lockdown era, when we were able to wander the Hayward Gallery and bathe in the sea of pulsating colour that was Riley’s superb exhibition. This screenprint is from a series that vibrates right off the paper (Tate owns an edition of Elongated Triangles 5, so you’ll be in good company if you get your hands on this one).The essence of things is what Michael Craig-Martin seeks in his work, and colour is part of seducing the viewer to really look at the objects that make up our world. These sculptural reliefs in polished steel come from a series that pays homage to designers and architects whose vision has shaped what we think of as “modern”. You can’t sit on them, but look at them.
