title: covid london north west highest unemployment
story: The London Boroughs of Brent, Barking and Dagenham and Newham, along with towns like Blackpool could see  per cent of their population out of work, according to the influential Joseph Rowntree Foundation.The charity is warning that there is no one-size-fits-all recovery and urges the Government to take targeted action that pulls these places back from the brink of surging levels of poverty.They are calling for Whitehall to work locally to prevent potentially millions being pushed into poverty.Their data highlights that certain Outer London boroughs, signicant parts of the West Midlands and pockets in the North-East and North-West are at greatest risk of bearing the full force of the surge in unemployment and poverty making it harder to recover.Seaside towns and ‘red wall’ seats that helped deliver the Conservatives’ election win last year are also facing a tough recovery.They say that tourism and manufacturing jobs are at the highest risk of disappearing.Dave Innes, Head of Economics at the Joseph Rowntree Foundation, said: “It can only be right that the places hardest hit by the ongoing economic crisis are the first priority of the recovery.“Towns and cities which are already on the brink need urgent support to prevent a surge in poverty caused by rising unemployment.“There is no one-size-fits-all recovery and many parts of Britain can’t afford the price of inaction.“The Government has the chance to provide the skills and opportunities each part of our country needs to thriveit targets investment where it is needed most.”They are calling on ministers to bring forward investments in targeted support, skills, and retraining schemes, to benefit the groups of workers in sectors most at risk of job losses, like adults over  with fewer formal qualications, women and those in the BAME communities.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: lebanon president knew huge explosives weeks before blast
story: Michel Aoun revealed he learned about the stash of , tonnes of ammonium nitrate on July  but claims he ordered officials to deal with the problem so the tragedy is not his fault.The chemicals had been stored at a warehouse since  after being seized from a cargo ship, but Aoun insisted he had no authority to deal directly with the port. When asked whether he should have followed up on his order, he replied: Do you know how many problems have been accumulating There are ranks that should know their duties, and they were all informed, he added.When you refer a document and say Do what is needed - isnt that an order Its been revealed officials had raised the alarm over the powder keg of chemicals at least  times over the last seven years with one warning it could blow up all of Beirut.Aoun came to power in  but blames his predecessors for the disaster, reports Sky News.He said: The material had been there for seven years, since . It has been there, and they said it is dangerous and I am not responsible.I dont know where it was placed. I dont even know the level of danger. I have no authority to deal directly with the port.Aouns claims comes just hours after he said Tuesdays deadly explosion could have been caused by a “rocket or bomb.”He said that “the cause has not been determined yet” three days after the explosion devastated the port area of the capital.At least  people died in the blast and an estimated , were injured, while dozens remain missing.Many people are feared to still be trapped under the rubble and inside their damaged homes.And a desperate hunt has now been launched to find survivors.UNICEF is now warning that of those , left homeless by the blast, , are children.An investigative committee in Lebanon has been given four days to determine responsibility.In the wake of tragedy, demonstrators in Beirut have clashed with security forces as Lebanons ruling parties are blamed for the industrial blast.Many in the country say the tragedy was the result of corruption and negligence over the course of years as well as the influence of terrorist group Hezbollah in the countrys politics.The devastation came as the country was already in the midst of an economic crisis, facing spiraling debt, deteriorating public services and unemployment at  percent.Tracy Chamoun, Lebanons ambassador to Jordan, said the country needed a change in leadership, while MP Marwan Hamadeh said its ruling parties had destroyed and impoverished [Lebanon] in front of the world.Opposition figure Bahaa Hariri, son of former prime minister Rafiq Hariri, who was assassinated in , pointed the finger specically at paramilitary group Hezbollah, whose political wing is a dominant force in Lebanese politics.January saw the UK government add the entire Hezbollah movement to its list of terrorist organisations, where previously only its military wing had been included.The question we have to ask is how come for six years this combustible material was allowed to remain in the middle of this city of two million people  Hariri said.It is crystal clear Hezbollah are in charge of the port and the warehouse where the ammonium nitrate was stored.Nothing goes in and out of the Port or the Airport does so with them knowing. Nothing.Their decision to put it there in the middle of a city of two million people was an utter disaster. And now we have a destroyed city centre.Satellite images taken before and after the explosion showed the extent of the damage done to Beiruts main port, through which around  percent of the countrys grain imports pass.Countries around the world have pledged support for the rescue effort, including the UK.PM Boris Johnson said Britain stands ready to offer any support we can to Lebanon - and confirmed some caught up in the blast were Brits.He added: All of my thoughts and prayers are with those caught up in this terrible incident.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: schools reopen lunch september defy government
story: Parents are receiving emails from schools telling them they will educate their child only until lunchtime for at least one day a week, reports say.It comes after hardline teaching unions threatened many schools wont re-open at all in September amid fears over coronavirus safety measures. Some schools will be doing this twice a week and some may close at an earlier time on all five days. Head teachers claim schools need to close early so staff can carry out the extra safety measures caused by the pandemic, including more time for deep cleaning, Mail Online reports.One teacher has died from the virus in the UK - and they didnt pick it up from school, according to papers from the Government advisory group Sage.The average number of confirmed Covid- cases among children is close to zero and its believed no child has needed hospital treatment since the beginning of June.Three teachers needed hospital care over the same period.Several schools will reportedly send their children home early at least one afternoon a week so teachers can plan lessons and mark work.Teachers would do their marking while a teaching assistant would take over the class, but schools say this is dficult as teachers and students remain in a bubble.Its feared that children will miss out on more education after already losing almost half a year of schooling because of lockdown. Primary schools and nurseries began to reopen on June  for children in reception, Years  and  and in nursery. Education Secretary Gavin Williamson announced the Governments intention to send all pupils back to school for the start of the new academic year.Early finishes will also be an inconvenience to parents who are planning toto normal work routines by the autumn. Teachers are entitled to an amount of planning, preparation and assessment time during the school week, said Geoff Barton, of the Association of School and College Leaders.The need to keep pupils and adults apart in consistent bubbles may make this harder, and some schools may decide to close earlier than one day a week. Its an example of the dilemma facing schools in the autumn, he said.Shorter school days adds an extra layer of confusion for parents after teaching unions warned that many establishments wont open their doors in September. Dr Mary Bousted, joint head of the National Education Union, said that many schools would find opening their doors to pupils impossible, despite six months out of education for some kids.In a recorded Zoom meeting seen by the Daily , Dr Bousted told members they cant trust the Government advice and local areas should make their own rules.She said: “The latest iteration of government guidance is so unworkable that you cant trust it. Local authorities and schools should take the confidence to do what they can do and that will mean for many schools that they cannot have all children fully back in September.“Now, the Governments making threatening noises about that. title: what today pollen count uk level london
story: But just how bad is it for people suffering from hay fever  Here is todays pollen count, and advice on how you can protect yourself.Heres the pollen forecast for dferent regions of the UK as of Saturday, August , .According to the Met office, weed pollen is at a high risk during the good weather from plants like pellitory-of-the-wall, fat hen, nettle, mugwort and plantain.There will also be lots of fungal spores, especially Alternaria.The pollen count remains at high levels across much of England and Wales, with the pollen unlikely to let up until mid-week for most regions.London will be hit hard by the weed pollen and is a high count area.Pollen levels will be medium in Northern Ireland, North East England, and across Scotland.The level is low in Orkney  Shetland.To try and combat the effects of hay fever, you can try a number of things:In times of high pollen, do not cut grass or walk in grassy areas, do not keep fresh flowers in your home, smoke or dry clothes outside as they can catch pollen.There are two ways which might be useful for hay fever sufferers to track periods of high pollen.The Met Office issues a five day pollen forecast which monitors the pollen count across the UK which you can find here.Tech-savvy hay fever sufferers can also download the Hay Fever Relief app which can alert you to the daily pollen count updates as well as give you an expert treatment plan and allow you to track your symptoms.A pollen count is generated by measuring the number of pollen grains in a given volume of air, using a pollen trap.A count of  pollen grains or less is considered low, and a count of , pollen grains or more is considered high.Pollen counts tend to be higher in early morning and late evening, although they can sometimes be high all day long.If the grass is damp, the pollen peak will be later in the morning because the water evaporates before the pollen is released.Pollen rises in the air during the day and then descends at night, as the air cools.In rural areas, the evening peak tends to occur between pm and pm but in the city, where the air stays warmer for longer, the pollen descends later and levels tend to peak between pm and midnight or even later, which is why you may wake up sneezing in the night.Sunny days favour higher pollen counts and rain tends to wash the pollen away, whereas on a cloudy day, pollen builds up only to be released on the next sunny day.

story: NewsDominic Cummings urged to prove he didnt make second lockdown trip by ex-police chiefEXCLUSIVE: The former Chief Constable of Durham Mike Barton has called on Dominic Cummings to prove he did not flout the coronavirus lockdown with a second lockdown tripShareByJeremy ArmstrongPippa CrerarDaily Mirror Political Editor:,  AUG Updated:,  AUG NewsDominic Cummings is under pressure to explain his second lockdown trip " %, rgba, rgba, url"What is really going on in politics  Get our daily email briefing straight to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe former Chief Constable of Durham has called on Dominic Cummings to prove he did not flout the rules with a second lockdown trip. Pressure was growing on the Prime Minister’s chief aide to provide evidence of the claims which he made in the garden of No  after the Mirror revealed his first -mile lockdown trip to his parents. Mr Cummings has categorically denied that he was in Houghall Woods near their Durham home on the morning of Sunday April . But walkers Dave and Clare Edwards told police in a statement that they were ‘ certain’ that they had seen him. They have gone to the Independent Office for Police Conductabout how their report of the sighting was handled. Former chief constable Mike Barton, in charge when Durham was recognised as the best force in the country, told the Mirror: “It is the classic formula. Eventually the police get blamed. “If Mr Cummings has proof that he did not go to Durham on that day - then let’s just see it.” His former colleagues at Durham must now decide whether to approach Mr Cummings for a statement on the latest claims, or ask him to produce his evidence of his whereabouts that day. It is understood that the force took the advice of a top QC before releasing their statement after Mr Cummings’ now infamous trip to Barnard Castle to ‘test his eyesight’. Durham Police decided that he may have committed a “minor breach” of the rules on April  - his we’s birthday - but that no further action would be taken.  A spokeswoman for the IOPC said: “In accordance with the police complaints procedure, we have forwarded a complaint to Durham Constabulary. “It will now be a matter for the force to determine the next steps including whether this complaint merits referral to the IOPC.”Their statement came amid growing pressure on Boris Johnson to make public the evidence provided by his chief advisor about April .Dave and Clare, both , are not alone in thinking that Mr Cummings was in Houghall Woods on that day.  The joint Mirror andinvestigation has now tracked down four people who have reported sightings of him that morning. The first man got in touch with the Mirror after spotting him with a female companion in the area at around .am. Dave, who works in manufacturing, and Clare, a nurse and care home worker for  years, believe that they spotted him there with a group of people just after am. The fourth witness told us how he left his home at precisely .am on April  and was in the woods by around . to .am. He had not come forward before he spoke to the Mirror. He said: “I heard on the grapevine that he had been seen in the area of the woods before April . “It had been spoken about by people who had spotted him in the area. I left my house at .am on April .  “It was quite a warm day so it would have taken around  minutes to get there, I think that I saw him around .-.am. “It was on the section going down towards the Botanical Gardens, towards Houghall Farm in the area at the back of Houghall Agricultural college.“At first I could not quite believe that I had seen him. I thought ‘why would he be up here ’ But I was sure about it at the time.”Clare, , is “% certain” in her claims that she saw Mr Cummings. She added: “It would be great to seehe could produce anything.“I just want the truth to be out there.” A further witness told thethey saw Cummings back in north London, on Hampstead Heath, later the same afternoon. Mr Cummings has described accusations that he made a second lockdown trip to the North East as “”. That denial came after we revealed in May that he drove  miles with his we Mary Wakefield, who had Covid- symptoms, and son to self isolate at his parents’ home near Durham on March , at the height of the lockdown.  During their two-week stay, the family went to Barnard Castle,  miles away, which he later claimed was to test his eyesight before the next day’s drive to London. A No spokesman said that Durham Constabulary had made clear that ‘they are not taking further action against Mr Cummings’ and that by locating himself at his father’s premises he did not breach the regulations. “The Prime Minister has said he believes Mr Cummings behaved reasonably and he considers the matter closed,” they added. Durham Constabulary said: “As outlined in our statement of May , we carried out an investigation into this matter led by a senior detective and found insufficient evidence to support the allegation.” But questions were asked about the PM’s decision to back Mr Cummings after it had been revealed he broke the Government’s rules, prompting public outcry and damaging confidence in lockdown restrictions. In his Downing Street garden press conference, Mr Cummings told reporters: “There is a particular report that I ed there on April th. Photos and data on my phone prove this to be . And local CCTV,it exists, would also prove that I’m telling the truth that I was in London on that day. I was not in Durham.”

title: what new dominic cummings allegations
story: NewsWhat new Dominic Cummings allegations mean and why they matter - timelineBoris Johnsons senior aide faces fresh questions about his lockdown trip after a new story in the Daily Mirror. Heres what the new allegations are, why they matter, and a timeline piecing the case togetherShareByPippa CrerarDaily Mirror Political EditorDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  AUG Updated:,  AUG NewsDominic Cummings originally came under fire for travelling  miles during coronavirus lockdown" %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailDominic Cummings faces calls to produce evidence proving he didnapost make a second lockdown trip after a new story by the Daily Mirror. Our front page today reports the account of witnesses who believe they saw the PMaposs top aide near Durham on the morning April .That is almost a week after he ed to London. Yet Mr Cummings categorically denies he made a second trip up north, and says he has evidence to prove it. Todayaposs story has come to light after two of the alleged witnesses, Clare Edwards, , and her husband Dave, complained to the Independent Office for Police Conduct. Clare believes her allegation that she saw Mr Cummings on April  was not taken seriously enough by officers. Given itaposs months now since the original story, it can be hard to grasp what this all means, and why it matters. So here is an explainer.What did Dominic Cummings do  The Tory adviser drove  miles with his we, who had Covid- symptoms, and son to self-isolate at his family farm near Durham on March  at the height of the lockdown. The next morning Mr Cummings himself fell ill, and the family proceeded to stay for two weeks, including a night when his son ended up in hospital, although he tested negative. During their stay, the family went to Barnard Castle,  miles away, on April , which Mr Cummings later claimed was to test his eyesight before the drive to London the next day. Mr Cummings admitted the trip but claimed he had not broken the rules. That is despite the rules at the time clearly banning non-essential travel, or leaving your home at allyou or a member of your household had symptoms. He claimed he was exempt from these rules because he needed to seek childcare for his son, in case he fell too ill to care for him. But he admitted he did not, in the end, need childcare. He ed to London on April .  What did police do  Durham Police investigated, and concluded on May  that there might have been a minor breach of the Regulations that would have warranted police intervention. However, the force added: Durham Constabulary view this as minor because there was no apparent breach of social distancing. Had a Durham Constabulary police officer stopped Mr Cummings driving to or from Barnard Castle, the officer would have spoken to him, and, having established the facts, likely advised Mr Cummings toto the address in Durham, providing advice on the dangers of travelling during the pandemic crisis. Had this advice been accepted by Mr Cummings, no enforcement action would have been taken. They also took witness statements and a photograph from the Edwardses on May , after being contacted by the couple. In their statement on May  they concluded there was insufficient evidence to investigate further.  What are new witnesses saying  A man got in touch with the Mirror on April , claiming he saw Mr Cummings with a female companion in Houghall Woods at . that morning. But in a press conference in the No garden in May, Mr Cummings denied this claim – saying: Photos and data on my phone prove this to be . Since then, three other people who claim to have seen Mr Cummings on April  have come forward.Clare Edwards, , said she is “% certain” she saw Boris Johnson ’s chief adviser while walking in Houghall Woods near Durham on the morning of Sunday, April . Her husband Dave claims to have seen Mr Cummings too. Clare and Dave have now comp­lained to the Independent Office for Police Conduct, claiming Durham police did not properly investigate their allegations about Mr Cummings. Another new witness claims to have seen Mr Cummings and a female companion walking between the beauty spot and the family home that morning between . and .. Another person then said they think they saw Mr Cummings on Hampstead Heath in North London that afternoon, four hours later at .pm. A test-drive of the route on a quiet Sunday after lockdown took three hours and  minutes.  How is this dferent to what we knew already  It is all about the date. The people who have spoken to the Mirror believe they saw Mr Cummings near Durham on April . That is almost a week after Mr Cummings ed to London from his two-week stay with his family. If Mr Cummings was in Durham on the morning of April , which he has previously denied, it would mean he made a second trip during lockdown. And that he misled both the PM - who spent six hours discussing the matter with him - and the public.  Why does it matter  Firstly, Dominic Cummings categorically denied that he had made a second trip to Durham during lockdown. So the claims suggest that either the witnesses were mistaken, or that Mr Cummings did make a second trip but said otherwise. Secondly, Mr Cummings said he had evidence to prove he did not make a second trip to Durham. Boris Johnson also suggested he had seen this evidence, saying:it pleases you I will say yes, I did. So the new claims add pressure on Mr Cummings or Downing Street to say what this evidence was. Thirdly, Mr Cummings gave a detailed -controversial - reasoning for travelling up north at the end of March. If he had travelled up north a second time, which he denies, this reasoning would be discredited. And fourthly, the law still banned leaving oneaposs home without reasonable excuse on April . A second trip would raise questions about whether this was followed.  What happens now  Labour have now demanded Dominic Cummings produce the evidence to prove he did not make a second trip to the north east during lockdown.Deputy leader Angela Rayner said: The public have a right to know whether the Prime Minister’s chief advisor made a second lockdown-breaching trip to Durham, and it is surely therefore only right that this evidence is produced. If Dominic Cummings was in London during both the morning and afternoon of the th April, and not in Durham as has been alleged, I’m sure that he the Prime Minister will welcome this opportunity to set the record straight.Former North West prosecutor Nazir Afzal, whose brother died of coronavirus, has launched his own appeal for evidence after accusing the police forces who investigated the case of ”closing ranks”.He said today: “Mr Cummings stated that he was not in Durham at any time on the th, he and these witnesses cannot both be right. “The failure of the police to investigate remains very disappointing given the public interest and concern.” The Met Police is also coming under pressure to investigate the allegations from, among others, the chair of Londonaposs Police and Crime Committee. But a No spokesman said yesterday: “Durham Constabulary have made clear they are not taking any further action against Mr Cummings and that by locating himself at his father’s premises he did not breach the regulations. “The Prime Minister has said he believes Mr Cummings behaved reasonably and he considers the matter closed.” Durham Constabulary said: “As outlined in our statement of May , [we] carried out an investigation into this matter led by a senior detective and found insufficient evidence to support the allegation.” Timeline of events Monday  March: Prime Minister Boris Johnson advises everyone in the UK to stop non-essential contact with others and to stop all unnecessary travel.Monday  March: In an evening TV address, the PM announces a UK-wide lockdown - effective immediately - to contain the spread of the virus. The public are instructed that they must stay at home from that evening, except for four very limited purposes - shopping for necessities, one form of exercise per day, any medical need, and travelling to and from workneeded. Public gatherings of more than two people, unless from the same household or under an exception, are banned effective immediately. Thursday  March: The lockdown restrictions that the PM launched on  March formally take force in law at pm, with £ fines for first-time offenders who break the rules. The three-day lag is due to the need to pass legislation through Parliament.Friday  March: Dominic Cummings is spotted running out of No to rush home to his we, who is ill with coronavirus symptoms. The family travel up to his parents’ home near Durham that weekend. Cummings later falls ill with the virus, but they do not need childcare for their four-year-old son as his we recovers. Tuesday  March: Durham Police have said they were “made aware” that the PM’s top aide was in the area and spoke to his father, although it is unclear whether they approached him or the other way round.Sunday  April: Cummings is seen standing outside the family property with a little boy and Abba blasting out on the radio. Downing Street declines to comment.Sunday  April: The family are seen at Barnard Castle,  miles away, by retired chemistry teacher Robin Lees on a trip which Cummings later claimed was to test his eyesight before the long drive back to London. It was also Cummings’ we’s birthday.Monday  April: Cummings travels back to London and the following day is seen at Downing Street.Friday  April: Cummings is among senior aides who visit the Prime Minister at Chequers.Sunday  April .am – witnesses claim they spot Dominic Cummings looking at bluebells in Houghall Woods. Downing Street says that Cummings is in London.am – Clare and David Edwards claim they see him with a group of people by the side of a path in the woods..-.am – a fourth witness alleges that the Prime Minister’s top aide walks past them between the woods and his parents’ home..pm – a member of the public claims that they see Cummings and his family on Hampstead Heath, North London. Cummings has denied being the person seeen. Thursday  April: We Mary Wakefield writes about the family’s self-isolation in the Spectator magazine - and talks of emerging from quarantine  into the almost comical uncertainty of London lockdown.Sunday  May:Boris Johnson addresses the nation to confirm he will ease lockdown - but people in England can only meet one person from another household, in public, and not stay overnight.Friday  May: The Mirror and thebreak the story that Dominic Cummings made a trip to Durham during lockdown. No  sources claim he had not broken the rules because he and his we had needed his parents to look after their son while they were ill.Monday  May: Dominic Cummings gives an extraordinary press conference in the No garden. He says the trip to Barnard Castle was to test his eyesight, and admits he went back into  Downing Street in person after visiting his sick we Mary on March . However, he denies making a second trip up north after hison April , saying: Photos and data on my phone prove this to be .

Proud parents Connie Yates, , and Chris Gard, , immediately fell in love with their baby son, born one day after Charlie would have turned four. Pictures show Miss Yates holding baby Gard for the first time, cuddling him into her chest in a white towel. Their little bundle of joy, not yet named, was born after a successful caesarean on Wednesday night weighing lb oz on Wednesday night. His parents gushed over the uncanny resemblance to his big brother Charlie. They wept with joy and said he was the spitting image of Charlie, who died or a rare genetic condition shortly before his first birthday in . Speaking after the birth, Mr Gard told the Mail Online: We are extremely tired but do not want to sleep as we just want to look at him the whole time. He’s absolutely gorgeous and has passed every medical examination he’s been given. Mr Gard said it was a truly magical and extremely emotional moment and the couple were overjoyed to hear their son was a perfectly healthy boy. She was pictured for the first time in her hospital gown beaming at her baby boy nestled in her arms. Speaking to the Daily Mail, Mr Gard added: The world feels a whole lot more beautul this morning. We’ve had about an hour’s sleep between us, but we just can’t stop looking at him. Connie was amazing, as always. He looks so similar to Charlie at the same age, it’s quite uncanny. It’s scary looking back at photos of Charlie and looking at our new baby. Spitting image. Miss Yates and Mr Gard tearfully gave up their legal battle to keep -month old Charlie alive in July  with his condition having deteriorated too far. The tragic tot died from mitochondrial depletion syndrome, a rare genetic condition causing progressive muscle weakness and brain damage. During Charlieaposs short le, his parents said their first born might have been able to live a normal lehe had received experimental US treatment earlier but too much time was wasted. They were blocked by hospital chiefs but their cause gained support from millions worldwide including the Pope.  During their legal battle at the High Court, Appeal Court and Supreme Court, Charlieaposs dad held a cuddly monkey which was his sonaposs favourite toy. The couple placed a baby version of the monkey next to their new son after his birth in a touching reminder of his big brother. Charlieaposs little brother had a one in four chance of being born with the same illness but tests prior to birth showed he is free of the condition. Further tests were carried out after his birth at Queen Charlotteaposs and Cha Hospital in west London. Mr Gard added: They have been amazing from start to finish. They knew the history and have done everything possible for us.  And now here we are, with the baby we have craved in our arms. He is a perfectly healthy boy. We’ve now been told this on numerous occasions. It is just music to our ears, because we went through such hell last time. It is one of le’s true miracles, watching your child being born, and this was no dferent for us. It was a truly magical and extremely emotional moment. Now we have genuine smiles on our faces. Before his arrival, Miss Yates said she was terried of giving birth for a second time.

The plane taking  passengers to Manchester took off just  metres from the end of the runway at Lisbon Airport in Portugal on September , . The pilots realised something was wrong as they were thundering down the runway and saw red and white flashing lights indicating they had m left. The Airbus A- passed over the end of the runway at a height of ft. An Air Accidents Investigation Branch report said there were “several obstructions beyond the runway that could have caused signicant damage to the aircraft and its occupants”. The two pilots had used tablet computers to work out the acceleration needed to get airborne. They meant to input that they were starting their take-off from ,m up the two-and-a-half mile runway at the point of an intersecting taxiway called S. But they wrongly inputted that they were starting from taxiway S at the start of the runway. The autopilot assumed they had an extra ,m to take off, and reduced their initial speed to compensate.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailFace mask rules have changed again today in England - here is everywhere you now need to wear them. Under new guidelines released by the Government, as of Saturday August  the number of places where it is compulsory to wear a face covering has increased. People will need to wear face coverings in cinemas, theatres, museums and places of worship, Yorkshire Live reports. Masks have been mandatory in shops since July  and are required to travel on public transport. But The PM announced he would extend the requirement to wear a face covering to other indoor settings. Boris Johnson said last week they will be compulsory in indoor settings where people are likely to come into contact with others they do not know. See below for the full list of where face coverings will need to be worn. Speaking at a Downing Street press briefing, Mr Johnson said: We will also extend the requirement to wear a face covering to other indoor settings where you are likely to come into contact with people you do not normally meet, such as museums, galleries, cinemas and places of worship. We now recommend face coverings are worn in these settings, and this will become enforceable in law from August . The Prime Minister added: Most people in this country are following the rules and doing their best to control the virus.  But we must keep our discipline and our focus and we cannot be complacent. I have asked the Home Secretary to work with the police and others to ensure the rules which are already in place are properly enforced. This means a greater police presence to ensure face coverings are being worn where this is required.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailIf anyone had told us on New Yearaposs Eve that we would spend the first half of  baking banana bread, doing puzzles and and jumping around the living room to a PE lesson hosted by Joe Wicks, we probably would have simply laughed.But as our Very Big Family Survey - conducted with Very - has proven, lockdown left us all with hours and hours of free time as we were asked to stay indoors to do our tiny bit to save lives.Without school, socialising, clubs, sport and - for some furloughed parents - work, families across the UK needed new ways to keep themselves busy. To fill the time, many people have taken up new hobbies and some families have said their new shared interests have brought them closer together - and they plan to continue them going forward. As the governmentaposs restrictions ease, the Very Big Family Le Survey with Very has looked back at how we all spent the strictest months of lockdown and how people view the “new normal”.Both kids and their parents have the opportunity to do new things, with  per cent of mums and dads with teenage kids saying theyaposve tried something for the first time or more often than normal. Cooking and baking is the most popular aposnewapos activity, with  per cent of parents with teenagers and  per cent of people with younger kids surveyed listing it. Gardening and exercise were next up on the list in both groups. Meanwhile, their kids have also enjoyed cooking and baking, at  per cent, while  per cent have tried their hand at gardening. Arts and crafts and growing their own fruit and veg also made the top five.Interestingly, the exclusive Daily Mirror and Very survey showed that gardening was far lower down the list for kids younger than , with exercise in second place after cooking and baking.Boys were more likely to have spent more time playing a musical instrument and doing DIY. And for many, the group activities have brought them together as a family. Describing the positives of lockdown, one parent wrote: Being able to help more with the kids home schooling as normally I am in work. Building a veg garden and growing our own veg has been a fun thing for all of us.  And I feel we have all grown closer as a family. Meanwhile, other families used the opportunity to exercise and to improve their fitness. Some even opted to do this all together, either through group work outs or by making it a competition. One parent said: Getting myself fitter by running more on my treadmill. The rest of family doing it as well, so we are fitter as a family physically and mentally. Some made the most of their one trip out of the house for exercise by going out for a walk with loved ones. One wrote: Going for a walk with my daughter and spotting all the wildle and breathing cleaner air. Another added: Going out for walks and discovering areas around where I live that I never knew were there. While everyone has obviously faced their own challenges in lockdown, some people have found itaposs also brought some advantages, Veryaposs research found. Parents of younger kids are more likely to have found the lockdown fun compared to those with teenage children, but an incredible amount say the restrictions have brought them closer as a family.

Normally, Her Majesty joins the congregation at nearby Crathie Kirk, but this year it is understood she will not take her seat in the Aberdeenshire place of worship. Lockdown measures have been reintroduced in Aberdeen following the outbreak of a coronavirus cluster in the city. Face coverings are to be made mandatory in more indoor places across Scotland following the spike in cases. Follow all coronavirus updates on our live blog here The Queenaposs annual visit to Balmoral Castle was already expected to be dferent from normal due to the coronavirus restrictions in place. Crathie Kirk - a regular place of worship for the royal family when they are in residence at the estate - is among the places subject to rules allowing communal prayer for a maximum of  people, with two-metre distancing in place. A Buckingham Palace spokesman previously said arrangements for the Queenaposs stay in Scotland will be in line with the relevant guidelines and advice.  The Queen and Prince Philip had been shielding at Windsor Castle since the start of lockdown. They were driven from Windsor to RAF Northolt in London earlier this week, where they then boarded a plane heading to the ,-acre Aberdeenshire estate, where they are expected to stay until at least September. They will be joined by whataposs been dubbed their aposBalmoral Bubbleapos, a small team of key staff who will look after them during their stay.It includes master of the household Vice-Admiral Tony Johnstone-Burt, the Queenaposs private secretary Sir Edward Young and Paul Whybrew and William Henderson, her pages. The Aberdeen lockdown had been rolled out again as a surge in cases has heightens fears the Scottish Government is dealing with a signicant outbreak in Aberdeen that may include some community transmission, Ms Sturgeon said. A five-mile travel rule has been put in place and residents are being told not to enter each otheraposs houses and indoor and outdoor hospitality venues must close.

Bleach and vinegar are routinely used in households to keep bathrooms and kitchens free of dirt and grime. But many people are apparently unaware that combining both some chemicals can create a highly dangerous toxic gas.  Australian consumer advocacy group CHOICE issued the warning to consumers.They said: “Warning: Never mix bleach and vinegar together – it creates toxic chlorine gas.” If you do accidentally mix the products together, you should immediately leave the area and try and breathe in some fresh air. Also change and wash any clothes that have been contaminated. You may notice irritation of your nose, mouth, and throat. Vinegar is often used as a natural compound unlike man-made chemicals such as bleach. While both are lauded for their stain-removing qualities, both together are a lethal combination.Bleach is made of diluted sodium hypochlorite while vinegar is a diluted form of acetic acid, reports OK! Magazine.Inhaling a small amount of this will irritate your throat, nose and eye while a large dose of this gas has the potential to kill  “Unlike some other dangerous chemicals like carbon monoxide, chlorine gives off a distinctly pungent and irritating odor, it says on Healthline. They continued: If you notice a strong smell after mixing cleaners, it’s a good idea to immediately leave the area.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailBritain could be at risk of a Beirut-style explosion, it is feared, as a port prepares to store almost twice as much a­mmonium nitrate as went off in the Lebanese capital. It is not yet certainthe tragedy which killed at least  people on Tuesday was an accident or terrorism. Lebanon’s President Michel Aoun said: “There is a possibility of a rocket or bomb or other act.’“ The blast, which flattened much of Beirut’s port, was caused when a fire set off a ,-ton pile of ammonium nitrate in a warehouse. But shipping company Portico wants permission to store up to , tons in ­Portsmouth, Hants. The firm insists the plan is safe. But there are fears over the risk posed by the chemical, used in ­fertiliser. Terror group Hezbollah has previously threatened to use it as a weapon and MI foiled a plot in London five years ago.Last year Hezbollah chief Hassan Nasrallah claimed he was storing the substance in Haa, Israel, adding: “A few missiles hit the tanks [and] tens ofthousands will be killed.”Haras Rafiq, who has sat on ious government taskforces combating extremism and terrorism, said of Nasrallah’s grim boast: “In that video, he states it wouldn’t take much to turn that stored chemical into deadly bombs.  We certainly need to be more vigilant when looking at Hezbollah and how it operates globally.” Three tons of ammonium nitrate were found in four London properties in . A man in his s was arrested but later released. Meanwhile, Portico defended its ­Portsmouth plan, saying: “These goods are handled on a regular basis in ports and held in larger quantities in agricultural businesses.  Strict inspections are in place, our licence is for the smaller, lower risk amount.” Portsmouth City Council leader Gerald Vernon-Jackson added: “Every port in the country imports fertiliser. It will be trucked out, it won’t sit around.”

title: voice mirror dominic cummings free
story: NewsopinionVoice of the Mirror: Dominic Cummings has a free pass that symbolises the Prime Ministers arroganceBoris Johnson’s regime has further undermined its fragile trust by sticking up two fingers at people over the behaviour of privileged No adviser Dominic Cummings who broke the lockdown rulesShareByVoice of the Mirror:,  AUG NewsopinionDominic Cummings " %, rgba, rgba, url"What is really going on in politics  Get our daily email briefing straight to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailDowning Street’s contempt for the British public is corrosive. Boris Johnson’s regime has further undermined its fragile trust by sticking up two fingers at people over the behaviour of privileged No adviser Dominic Cummings. In defying the growing clamour to respond to witnesses insisting they saw Cummings on a second lockdown-breaking visit to County Durham, suspicions understandably rise about what the Government has to hide. The head of Westminster’s all-party Public Accounts Committee, Meg Hillier, has asked to “have the truth out in the open”. It is a legitimate appeal for transparency that a Downing Street confident of its position would be falling over itself to meet. Johnson giving Cummings a free pass symbolised the arrogance of a Prime Minister who behaves asrules are for the little people. If Cummings has evidence that he is not a serial offender, let him publish or be damned. Hard Prest PRESTON in Lancashire is the latest town to be put under local lockdown – worrying evidence that this virus is not beaten. This crisis could go either way, with the Office for National Statistics suggesting the number of infections in England may be levelling off – while experts on the Scientic Advisory Group for Emergencies recently warned “it does not have confidence” that the vital R reproduction rate is below one in England.  Imposing local restrictions inconveniences families but the measures are necessary. It’s better to lock down areas where the virus surges now than risk a second shutdown of the entire country in the coming winter.

title: persistent hiccups could new symptom
story: NewsPersistent hiccups could be a new symptom of coronavirus, doctors warnDoctors in Chicago say hiccups should not be dismissed as a symptom after a man who tested positive for the deadly disease had hiccups for four daysShareByDanya BazaraaSenior News Reporter:,  AUG Updated:,  AUG NewsPeople being tested for coronavirus" %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailDoctors are warning persistent hiccups could be a possible new symptom of coronavirus. A report published in the American Journal of Emergency Medicine describes the case of a man who tested positive for the deadly disease after having hiccups for four days. The -year-old, from Chicago, had initially showed no other symptoms. He was admitted to hospital and when he had his temperature checked it was .C. But a scan on his lungs showed indications that he was struggling with his lung capacity. The man was put in an isolation room where he was tested for coronavirus. His temperature later increased to .C. The report stated: Here we present a case of persistent hiccups as the presenting symptom of a Covid- infection in a -year-old man. To our knowledge, this is the first case report of persistent hiccups as the presenting complaint in a Covid- positive patient in emergency medicine literature. The doctors from Cook County Health, Chicago, said patients with hiccups should not be dismissed, the Sun reports.  They added: Physicians should keep Covid- infection on their dferential as more cases are discovered through atypical presentations. The NHS states the official symptoms of Covid- as a high temperature, a new and continuous cough, and a loss or change to your sense of smell or taste.

title: mum defends dressing kids cheap
story: NewsMum defends dressing kids in cheap clothes - while she wears expensive onesCaitlin Fladager, , from Vancouver, Canada, has hit back at Facebook trolls after being shamed for her decision to dress her children in clothes from Walmart while she wears glamorous outfitsShareByKelly-Ann Mills:,  AUG NewsCaitlin Fladager doesnt feel bad her children wear cheaper clothes " %, rgba, rgba, url"News, views and top stories . Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA mum has defended her decision to dress her children in supermarket clothes while she wears fancier outfits. Caitlin Fladager hit back after being told it was not a good look for you as a mum...” The -year-old from Vancouver, Canada, proudly admits to buying her clothes from ious fashion brands, while most of daughter Ariana and son Jackaposs outfits are bought from Walmart. You know why  she fired back. Because I am not constantly outgrowing them, like my kids are.The mum, who last year defended smoking cannabis while looking after her children, added that the youngsters liked the freedom that it didnapost matterthey got the cheap clothes messy. In a Facebook post, she wrote: “‘You get dressed up a lot. Not a good look for you as a mom…’ That statement is something I get a lot.“Yes, my kids clothes mostly come from Walmart, while I buy myself clothes from other stores. “You know why  Because I am not constantly outgrowing them, like my kids are.” She added: “I am not constantly spilling food and dirt all over my brand new clothes. “I am not outside running around in the dirt for hours on end. “I am not tripping and ripping holes in brand new clothes. “I am not changing my mind daily about what colour I have randomly decided I don’t want to wear ever again. “I am not a kid.” Caitlin argued: “My children are messy, they love to play in the dirt, and they love to spill their food. “I buy them cheaper clothes, because I refuse to be the mom who yells at them for spilling a drop of ice cream on a brand new shirt. “I strive to be the mom who sees them spill, and says “oh no big deal!  “I strive to be the mom who sees them playing in the dirt, not caring that they are ruining a brand new outfit. “I strive to be the mom who teaches them there is more to le than having nice, expensive clothes.” She added: “So yes, my kids mainly live in Walmart clothes. And they love it. “They love being able to spill, get dirty, and outgrow clothes in a day with me not caring. “So here’s my kids, in an outfit I bought not long before this day. “Here’s them covered in dirt, spilling ice cream, and living their best le. That’s all I could ever want.  ”I will not feel bad for buying my clothes for them from Walmart. Because when I look at this picture, it reminds me why I do that. “The dirt, the smiles, and the ice cream makes me way more happier than a photo of them dressed in clothes they hate, that they will outgrow in a week. “This right here, makes me so much happier.” Caitlin’s post racked up more than , likes and hundreds of comments with most parents agreeing with her message.  One said: As long as they are dressed and happy who cares. “I would rather buy Walmart clothes and be able to take them to do other things and make memories, because I donapost remember what I wore everyday at . “Do you  Probably not – you more than likely remember the memories made at the time. Not the clothes. So great job momma!”

title: chancellor rishi sunak rules out extra treasury cash for aberdeen to ease the blow of return to lockdown
story: Chancellor Rishi Sunak has indicated the Treasury will not provide extra cash for Aberdeen to help the city with the reintroduction of lockdown restrictions.On a visit to Scotland, Mr Sunak said it was for the Scottish Government to provide support during local lockdowns, as he warned the UK Government’s furlough scheme cannot go on indefinitely.The UK Government has spent £. billion supporting the payrolls of . million workers, including almost one million Scots, during the coronavirus crisis. But Mr Sunak confirmed the furlough scheme will end in October.“Eight months of support from start to finish is a considerable period of time for the government helping to pay people’s wages and I just don’t think that is something that can go on indefinitely.”Chancellor Rishi SunakHeading north of the border to publicise the billions that the Treasury has spent on supporting people during the pandemic, Mr Sunak was askedthere would be more help for Aberdeen.“The Scottish Government no doubt will be talking to Aberdeen and providing whatever support they think is appropriate in those circumstances,” the Chancellor said.Mr Sunak added that local business support was a “devolved matter” and therefore the responsibility of the Scottish Government.“The Scottish Government has done slightly dferent things in how they’ve decided to support businesses and that’s absolutely their right and I’m sure they will be looking at that,” he added.The Chancellor also repeated the UK Government’s line that now was not the time for a second Scottish independence referendum because efforts should be focused on recovering from the coronavirus crisis.With the SNP riding high in the polls, he also expressed the hope that, as time went on, voters would acknowledge the billions of pounds the UK Government had provided during the crisis.#I would hope that people when they go through this and reflect on what’s happened they can see the benefit of the Union. It is not just the economic measures, jobs in Scotland are equally as important to me as equally anywhere  in the United Kingdom. As we think about our recovery measures that we are putting in place again it will benefit jobs everywhere, but especially jobs in Scotland with regards tourism.#On the health side there has been an enormous amount of collaboration whether it has been on testing, PPE or vaccines and bit by bit I hope those are the kinds of arguments that people will see the benefit of the Union.#Mr Sunak argued UK schemes such as Eat Out to Help Out and VAT reductions in the tourism sector can#disproportionately benefit the Scottish economy  and Scottish jobs and in doing so help drive the UK recovery#.He said: #So to me, all of that experience shows me the Union has an enormous resonance today and hopefully people will recognise that.#The Chancellor also said he didn#t think #now is the time to be talking about these constitutional questions.#I think everyone#s sole focus, and certainly my sole focus right now, is doing what we can to protect people#s jobs and their livelihoods at what is an incredibly dficult time for our economy, and that#s what I think everybody should be focused on. Let#s not focus on these isive constitutional questions, let#s focus on rebuilding for the future.#On his trip to Glasgow and the Isle of Bute, he resisted calls for the furlough scheme to be extended beyond October.“Eight months of support from start to finish is a considerable period of time for the government helping to pay people’s wages and I just don’t think that is something that can go on indefinitely,” the Chancellor said.He argued that having people out of the labour market for a long period would not help their job prospects.“It would be easy to tell people it’s all going to be fine and that job will be there. That won’t be true for everybody and, in those circumstances, having people not attached to the labour market for that prolonged period of time is not doing them any favours.“All the academic evidence and practical economic evidence that we have on labour market outcomes tells us that. People not being attached to a workplace is not good for their long-term prospects. If it is not going to be the case that that job is going to be there, we are better off providing new opportunities and dferent types of support.”With people in Aberdeen potentially missing out on his Eat Out to Help scheme with theto lockdown, Mr Sunak appeared reluctant to make allowances for them.“We have kept it as a national scheme for the month,# he said. #We keep everything under review, but it is tricky to figure out exactly the right way to tweak that. It is complex. Hopefully what we see with these local lockdowns is that they are not going to be very long in duration,” the Chancellor said.The Federation of Small BusinessesScotland called for Aberdeen firms to receive more help.A FSB spokesman said: #The longer the Aberdeen lockdown continues, the more likely it is that businesses who, through no fault of their own, have been forced to close – or who remain open, but have seen footfall plummet – will need support.#The amount and nature of that support that will matter more to them than whether it comes from the Council, Holyrood or Westminster.  That said, we know that, as where in the UK, funds earmarked for local support grants in Scotland are underspent.  Re-purposing that cash to set up a support fund for businesses hit by local lockdowns would seem a sensible place to start.”For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles.Newsletter Get top stories straight to your inbox every day.SUBSCRIBE HERE!Latest blaize_config   n t t tCancelation Offer % - Web + ePaperGet unlimited access to the Eveningwebsite and Premium Content and all the benefits of the print paper in a digital replica of the Evening  n t t t t n t t t ua. per month  u recurring subscription n n t t t n t t t tEdition: n t t t tWeb + ePaper n t t t n t t t n t t t tDuration: n t t t t Month n t t t n t tSubscribe TodayEnjoy the digital edition of the Eveningnewspaper on your smartphone, tablet and computer.Unlimited access to all articles on the Eveningwebsite. title: dundee united micky mellon transfer news
story: There have been a smattering rather than a procession of new arrivals at Dundee United but boss Micky Mellon insists they are ‘on the front foot’ with their recruitment drive.Mellon has raided the English market since taking over the reins at Tannadice, bringing in Manchester City youngster Luke Bolton on loan and snapping up defender Ryan Edwards from Blackpool.The former Tranmere boss is reportedly chasing Ipswich stars James Norwood and Toto Nsiala and, although he is keeping his cards close to his chest, says United have a few irons in the fire.“We are in the market,possible, to make Dundee United’s squad stronger,” he said.“I am careful to say squad because we have good players here but we are in the market all the time to try and make that better.“It is a continual on-going job because that is my job.“We will get linked to all sorts of players because we speak to agents but we have to be respectful to other clubs and players.“The clubs would be the first place we would go towe were to try and pursue something.”He continued: “The recruitment market can change on the toss of a coin.“It can be one that happens right away or it could be a slow burner where you are continually prodding at it.“There are a few we are prodding at the moment and trying to shake and things can change very quickly.“We are on the front foot and trying to improve the squad with some strong characters as quickly as we can.”Dundee United new boy Ryan Edwards has already shown he can win the toughest of all battles" title"#Dundee United new boy Ryan Edwards has already shown he can win the toughest of all battles# # Evening " src"https:www.eveningtelegraph fp dundee-united-ryan-edwards-transfer-new embed # secretZEbtwHnk" data-secret"ZEbtwHnk" width"" "" frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"Centre-back Edwards will be in contention to make his United debut at Motherwell on Saturday as the Tangerines look to build on an opening day draw with St Johnstone.Whether the -year-old runs out at Fir Park is fitness pending. However, Mellon is just delighted to have signed up a man he feels will be a key part of what he’s building.He added: “I am delighted to get him in.“I came into the group and got underneath it before I made any decisions on what type of players I needed to bring in.“It became very clear to me that we needed that type of central defender to compliment what we have already got.“Ryan is a leader, fantastic competitor and a good all-round guy.“He has come up here with bags of ambition and is looking to do really, really well.“He has an ambition to make a real impact.“He’ll be a good addition to the squad along with Luke Bolton and we are pleased that we have strengthened the group.”Mellon thinks his latest recruit has everything it takes to be a success in Scotland after spells with the likes of Blackburn Rovers, Morecambe and Plymouth Argyle.“I saw him right back in his Blackburn days,” he continued.“He is a centre back I have known for a long time.“He is a good size, a good athlete and is a winner.“I know he will come up here, settle and do very well up here.“He is maybe a wee bit behind in fitness as he hasn’t done six weeks like we have done but we’ll gauge him along with Bolton andwe feel they#re ready for this weekend then we will put him in.”Off the pitch, Edwards is no stranger to battles, having come through the other side of a testicular cancer diagnosis three years ago.Having that kind of character in his ranks is vital for Terrors gaffer Mellon.“We have all been touched with stuff like that via all our families,” he said.“The boy has had to deal with that at a young age and he showed tremendous character to get through that.“Nobody can question Ryan’s character coming through something very serious like that.“He has done that and we are delighted to title: dundee united sporting director tony asghar urges fans not to ask for selfies or autographs
story: Dundee United sporting director Tony Asghar has pleaded with fans to keep their distance from players as the club copes with the coronavirus crisis.Prompted or not by the drama in Aberdeen, which has seen the Dons’ match against St Johnstone in Perth postponed, the Tangerines have urged supporters to refrain from asking for autographs and selfies.Ahead of the Tannadice club’s trip to Motherwell tomorrow, Asghar said: “With the football season under way, we still all have exceptional challenges to endure with Covid- and the safety of our whole community is paramount.“The club has worked tirelessly, and with great expense, to adhere to restrictions and measures implemented from the SFA SPFL Joint Response Group to make sure our players, coaches and performance staff are tested twice a week and conform to all medical advice to be able to train and play matches.“Our hope is that by doing this in the short term, we will soon see supporters at matches and players will eventuallyto a normal working environment.“However, I must stress that it is important that our fans support us during this time.“Over the past few weeks, there have been attempts made to approach players at the High-Performance Centreat the University of St Andrews to sign shirts and take selfies.“This is not acceptable and could seriously jeopardise the health of the players and also impact on the continuation our competitive matches.“Your support is fundamental to our players and staff but, at this present time, we cannot have anyone other than players and staff attending the HPC or the stadium on match days or approaching the players until we have clear indications of a change in the process.“Our players and staff are well aware of the ramications of this virus but they also find it dficult to turn down an advance of a fan as is human nature, especially for the type of player we have at Dundee United,” added Asghar.“However, I also know the core support of Dundee United FC will also adhere to this, so please spread the word to others. title: medical incident at slessor

title: sky customers frustrated as broadband issues leave thousands of scots without internet
story: Sky broadband customers in parts of Scotland have been left without internet after the service stopped working earlier today.Some customers said their broadband stopped working as early as .am, with others reporting the fault nearer midday.The internet provider became unavailable in many households across Dundee, Tayside and Fe, with text messages sent to some customers saying engineers were working on the issue.One Sky broadband customer in Dundee said: #It#s just frustrating. I work from home and need my computer to work. Thankfully I can use my mobile to access the internet on my computer, but my phone bill will be hugeI go over my data allowance.#Hopefully this is dealt with sooner rather than later.#The firm released a statement today saying: “We are aware there are issues with some of our broadband services in the east of Scotland today.#We have engineers working to resolve the issue as soon as possible and the majority of customers should now be back online. title: rachel corsie scottish premiership clubs covid 19 bubble was always vulnerable
story: It seemed inevitable eventually there would be a positive test at a Scottish Premiership club as part of the top-flight’s .From the outside, I was somewhat sceptical over the restart last weekend, based on the protocols which were being implemented, and I’ve been proven right with the two positive tests at Aberdeen.The protocol for clubs is largely based on good faith and that players and staff will act in a manner which keeps them within the “bubble”. It’s a particularly weak safeguard.Alongside this, the temptation to still carry out day-to-day activities, and the growing laxity in precautions being taken in the general population, meant it was only a matter of time before someone ed a positive test.After playing a part in a successful tournament-style season over in the US, I witnessed first-hand the protocols expected to be followed by players.As a league we were not entirely free from the controversy, as prior to our own start we also had one team caught out by the naivety of a few. This markedly similar incident resulted in the elimination of that team’s participation altogether, which was devastating to those who had followed the rules and also to the fans, sponsors and wider community who were impacted.While the final guidelines we had to follow were relentlessly strict and burdensome, they were ultimately essential to controlling the contact with anybody outside of our “bubble”.For us, partners and family were not allowed to enter our home environment after a pre-set tournament start date unless willing to also follow the safety rules.Meanwhile, trips to shops, cafes and supermarkets were absolutely forbidden for every player, and their respective household members, who had to adhere to the same sanctions once they chose to also be part of the safe zone which was created.Food was prepared and sent out through contactless delivery for every meal and the league carried out an anonymous honesty scheme, where any players caught in breach of the rules could be called out.The full guidelines we had to adhere to in the NWSL perhaps would never have been agreed to here because it would be deemed too much, but the control over exposure to any outside contact should certainly still remain one of the greatest priorities for the players and their immediate family.Theto football is something we are all excited about and hopeful for and – for players – there are additional moral obligations to act in a way which exceeds the precautions taken by the general public.Whether fair or not, the ramications and scrutiny over us is far greater than most, but ultimately we are the greatest beneficiaries because we get to play football every day and earn money doing so.Of course, we all want many things to be able toas they were before and I certainly didn’t enjoy living in the environment we were asked to in the United States.It was extremely isolating, I really missed being able to go to certain cafes and food stops and the daily tick-box requirements became draining over time. title: letters to the editor june 26 2020
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSir,In publishing the opinion piece #All lives matter# from your contributor on page  of the June  edition of the Argyllshire Advertiser, you have demonstrated a profound lack of understanding of the current Black Lives Matter protests.The tone-deaf piece is an attempt by your contributor to shut down engagement and perpetuate ignorance.How anybody can make the claim that all lives matter after witnessing such horric police brutality is beyond belief.All lives cannot matter until Black Lives Matter.Instead of deflecting and diluting the conversation, surely it is time to educate ourselves about what is happening, and to fight systemic injustice Madeleine Conn, ArdrishaigSir,The SNP continues to demonstrate its economic incompetence.New figures show the SNP government underspent its budget by a quarter of a billion pounds in -, and failed to use £ million of borrowing capacity. ​Instead of demanding further borrowing powers and more funding from the UK Government, the separatists should learn to use the resources they already have.With such colossal mismanagement, it#s no surprise that even senior SNP advisor Andrew Wilson has stated that Scotland is set to be the worst performing economy in the developed world. Once again, the separatists# numbers simply don#t add up.Councillor Alastair Redman # Kintyre and Islands wardSir,Exactly two years ago I was diagnosed with stage three, oestrogen positive breast cancer.I’d just come back from a week#s holiday in Spain with Isabel and Margaret. Days before I went on holiday I’d had a biopsy following referral from my GP. Although there wasn’t a cloud in the sky, my holiday was definitely clouded by impending results#I had chosen to wait until after my holiday to get them.The journey that Monday to go to Gartnavel is one I’ll never forget. My partner Frank didn’t shut up the whole way there, obviously he was nervous. I couldn’t be bothered with the small talk and just wanted him to shut up. Obviously I was nervous and he was just trying to keep my mind off it, but I was too busy silently praying. The number  is something I see all the time so I spent the whole journey looking for the number on someone’s licence plate #I saw it everything would be ok. I didn#t see it. That might sound a bit daft, but fear does crazy things to you.Walking into the consultant#s room and finding a nurse waiting there confirmed my worst fears. #It’s a wee cancer,# said Mr Wilson. The words echoing in my head, I couldn’t hear anything after that. I remember taking a deep breath and looking at Frank. I will never, ever forget the look on his face.My only question that day was #am I going to lose my breasts # The answer was no, and thankfully Frank was there to take in what was being said my head was spinning. The question I really wanted to ask was #am I going to die # I was too scared to ask that question.I didn’t cry until I walked out the hospital, then I bawled. Frank was amazing, and he didn’t talk like a budgie on the way home.The journey home was horrendous. I was terried about telling my mum. How do you tell your mum that her only child has cancer  I hadn’t told her anything about finding a lump. I couldn’t cope with worrying about her worrying about me # butit happens again I#d do it dferently and she’ll be the first to know. By the time I got home I had no more tears left.The relief telling mum was a huge weight off my shoulders. What ensued after my initial diagnosis was two weeks of crying every day. Telling the girls at work was so emotional, and in fact I was exhausted with it all.Once surgery and treatment plans were in place I was in a better place. Time to get the head down and get on with it, and that#s what I did. I was full of positivity and determination, and I think my sense of humour helped enormously.The treatment was bad, but it was necessary. The ongoing treatment is bad but it#s necessary. I’m alive and that’s what matters. My le has changed forever, nothing will be the same. My le has been ided into Before Cancer and After Cancer  I now have a new #normal#.I don’t know what the future holds, who does, but I intend to live my le happily, positively and most definitely to the fullest!I will never forget the support, both physically and emotionally that I received from my nearest and dearest, and of course from the whole community. The strength you have given me continues, and for that I am truly grateful.Please, pleaseyou find an abnormality or you just feel something isn’t quite right, act upon it and seek attention.I know it’s a dficult time with this horrid virus but it’s important to remember that early detection saves lives.Stay safe and take care.Yvie Young, Lochgilphead
